reviews.content: Let me get one thing straight. If you think you gonna read some sarcastic trash talk that makes fun of this movie you are wrong. Now that there is no room for any confusion here I go with my review. There are 2 crucial scenes that I cannot forget about this movie. Firstly: The scene where Johnny tells Mark " I think you should leave right now mark" after mark tells johnny "Lisa changed her mind about you wake up man what plan are you on?" Secondly: The scene where johnny kills himself and lies on the ground while mark Lisa and Denny still have some lines to say before the movie ends. In both scenes Tommy Wiseau's face and acting were so convincing that it just put me through a roller coaster of emotions. I mean I was just having fun, making fun of the scenes prior to these every thing was so funny the lines were so original and out of this world and at the same time hilarious the acting was theatrical, exaggerated and therefore can be considered bad for a movie... It didn't make any sense it was like watching an absurd comedy. But here is the important part for me. After these two scenes that I mentioned I wasn't laughing anymore. I was at such a state that I didn't give a single flying fudge about how nonsense the previous scenes about the movie were how I was making fun of the characters, the lines, the atmosphere, the conversations... none of these mattered at that point. I really felt sorry for what johnny was going through. Anyways in the end this original movie indeed changed my life. I wish I had watched it 14 years ago then by now I would be a much better man I'm sure of it. I always wanted to enjoy the life at its maximum limits. Think of a situation that you jumped from an airplane unwillingly without a parachute. What will you do at that point? will you cry knowing that inevitable death awaits you in a few seconds? (by the way according to a myth I heard in such situation you will die of a heart attack mid air because of the intense fear of death) or do you have the capacity to enjoy the feeling of the free fall despite the fact that you know you are going to die after you hit the ground so hard that your internal organs will scatter inside you? I dare you to think of this. Now I believe Tommy Wiseau is such a man, such a genius that would do the latter in this situation. This is what he did with his masterpiece The Room. He enjoyed the free fall.

reviews.review_title: The Room is so stupid that is funny
reviews.content: The Room is so stupid that is just pure funny. I laughed so hard i thought i would never stop laughing. The Room came out in 2003, but who cares this movie feels like it just got done being shot. Parents this movie is rated R and it shows why.

"Do you even understand life?!"It's as if all sense of awareness, urgency and charisma are sucked out of every single character (can we call them characters?!). The dialogue is mis-timed and jumbled (see florist conversation), the characters lack any sense of passion or arc, and while the direction gives us some great establishing shots of San Fransisco we remain trapped in the scrubby apartment these character's lives get entangled in. Someone drops in to say hi or something else pointless and meaningless to just leave 30 seconds later. Huh? Motives are questionable and literally slapped together with little to no thought involved. Someone will ask a question to say "I don't care" a second later. The list is endless. Let me just day if you're having a bad day or suffering from some sort of depression that this film is the cure. The only thing better than laughing your ass off at the bad lines and jumbled order of those same lines is watching other people react to this flawed masterstroke of incompetence.Then I checked the budget. 6 MILLION DOLLARS. For something that looks like it could have been put together by a high schooler. Basically, the only summation I can make is Tommy Wiseau is an enigma. Did he mean for the film to come out this way? Or is his version of reality so diluted we get that product on the screen? The world may never know.

reviews.review_title: Stop the madness!!!!!! This film deserves nothing more than 1 star!!!!!
reviews.content: I get it. "The Room" is the quintessential worst movie EVER made, hands down. It's hilarious...it really is. I understand why people love it; It's not a black comedy, it was never meant to be a comedy at all, in actuality it is a non-stop crap-fest that has you rolling with laughter because of its stupidity. The Room's mind-boggling story and atrocious acting, hits rock bottom of any film in the history of time. It doesn't get worse. Honestly. I really do get the appeal and I understand why "The Room" has a cult following. Please, I ask you humbly to stop giving this film (and other piles of #$%^) nine or ten stars. Do you realize by doing so, you are comparing the quality of these films to "The Shining", "Casablanca", "The Lord of the Rings" among countless other masterpieces. These classic films have earned their ten star ratings. Please quit compromising the quality of reviews on IMDb with these inflated ridiculous scores. It's not fair to the REAL filmmakers who have earned their stripes through years of work, and defined talent. It's also not fair to the consumer who buys "The Room" thinking it's a masterpiece and realizes two minutes in that they shouldn't have wasted their money.

Okay, there's no doubt about it that this movie sucks. However, this may be one of the most entertaining movies I have ever seen. I have been able to watch this film several times with friends and it is just as hilarious, if not more so, after each time I watch it. Tommy Wiseau has created an accidental cinematic treasure, although not in the way that he intended. If you can sit through and poke fun at the terrible acting, editing, music, and constant errors in the continuity of the story, I can guarantee that you will adore this movie like it's your own infant child.

reviews.review_title: I enjoyed this film more than most things I've seen lately.
reviews.content: Very easy to watch, exceptionally talented actors. Well done.

reviews.review_title: The king of "so bad its good"
reviews.content:
The acting is so terrible and stale. The dialogue is awkward and doesn't flow. I dare anybody to do a drinking game - one shot for every time they say "oh hi 'name'" and 5 shots for the infamous "oh hi Mark" line. There is just no chemistry or emotion between the characters or actors. They just seem like a bunch of fake friends pretending to like each other. The characters themselves were just dry and colorless and had no dimension at all. The story itself is stupid. Maybe different story arcs looked good on paper, but the execution was poor. And to top it all off, there are a few more sex scenes than necessary.Now that the complaints are out of the way, let me give credit where credit is due:
Everything that makes The Room bad is everything that makes The Room good.Of course it's a bad film, but it has its charms. The story of the Room was flawed, but it really did have some good themes in there, and its obvious that Wiseau tried his best to get different messages across, particularly through the use of Danny's character. Hearing about the making of the film is interesting as well and adds to the experience (watch Disaster Artist before and/or after watching the Room). My rating is 3/10 - 2 stars for the attempt of making a decent move, and 3 stars for Sir Tommy Wiseau.Tommy Wiseau gave it his all in this film. He wanted to make a movie, so he did. Though I'm sure the movie upon release was received poorly, he continues to work to this day and has many beloved fans that follow this cult classic. It's honestly inspiring that he achieved success, but in a way he probably wasn't expecting. As low quality as the Room is, it was at least entertaining. I plan to watch other Wiseau films someday, just to see how much has evolved, and to support an independent film maker who dedicates his life expressing himself through the art of film.

reviews.review_title: The best worst movie in history.
reviews.content: When you combine the simple love triangle story with the wierdest acting, dialoge and directing you have ever seen and then top it off with extra sub-plots that appear and disappear within single scenes you get a movie that has caused the definition of bad to collapse on itself and create a supernova of pure cinematic genius.

reviews.review_title: It's so bad that its actually really good
reviews.content: God! Help me!I will keep it simple. It's the worst movie I've ever seen but its so grotesque that is actually funny.

reviews.review_title: Murphy's Law in full effect: everything that could go wrong, went wrong
reviews.content: It's hard to add anything new to a movie that has been described as possibly the best worst movie ever made. It has been said to resemble a depiction of humanity as done by an alien who watched only 24 hours of our television, while others praise it as the best unintentional comedy ever made. Whatever the case may be, everyone who has ever used the term 'worst movie ever' on Godzilla, Waterworld or a Star Wars prequel/sequel should be forced to watch this movie and reconsider. Opinions vary on whether The Room is retrospectively brilliant in that it stumbled upon important themes of friendship, fate and betrayal, but it is generally agreed upon that its merits, bad or good, actively contribute to the fun of watching it. There's no better proof that entertainment can be independent of quality than this movie.In the amusing 'making of' movie The Disaster Artist, it is postulated that writer/actor/producer/director Tommy Wiseau survived a major accident years before he started his magnum opus that is The Room. I am extremely curious to know if this is what happened in real life, because it would explain a lot. As a student I learned that paintings and drawings made by patients with mental disorders could often be used to perfectly exemplify what their ailments were. If this comparison extends to all art in general, including film, then The Room is a look into an extremely fractured mind. This should be mandatory viewing for every medical student who ever considers neurology as a major.Because let's not fool ourselves: this must be the most disjointed and inconsequential movie ever made. Wiseau claims to have wanted to make a movie about 'human nature', and it looks like he decided to go through every type of human action and feeling imaginable in a mere 90 minutes, without any narrative, logical or dramatic cohesion. Normally, a plot is a course of events where one occurrance initiates another, but most of what happens in The Room is a non-sequitur. Of all the misery, joy and ill-defined stuff that happens over the duration of this movie, only a fraction seems to have any long-lasting effect on the plot or characters in one way or another. Drugs, disease, arguments, violence, love, sex and alcohol all pass by for the sake of human drama, characters come and go, but they are often forgotten by the next scene (or even in the same scene), to be never mentioned again or no longer be of significance. You could effectively edit out the entire second act without any negative bearing on the film's final act. This is the kind of film in which people don't seem to be doing anything, yet they claim to be busy; where mothers in 2003 still urge their daughters to marry for financial stability rather than love; where one of the actors was no longer available, so they gave his lines to a completely new character without any introduction, and where there is always time for a game of football without any symbolic or metaphorical meaning. The royal amount of sex scenes almost begs a comparison with a lot of soft-porn B-movies from a decade before, but even those had better writing, acting and directing. As hard as it is to believe, there was even supposed to be a subplot about vampires that didn't make it. Too bad, because it would have made this movie brilliant in its failure over multiple movie genres.Coupled with his complete lack of talent in telling a story, Wiseau doesn't seem to understand what natural dialogue sounds like. Almost all conversations contain something ridiculous, overblown, pompous, inappropriate or nonsensical. Much of the movie's cult appeal comes from endless repetitions, e.g. that Lisa looks beautiful, Johnny and Mark are best friends, the world is treacherous and people don't want to talk about stuff. But the true gold is in such classic quotes like "Oh hi, Mark!", "You are tearing me apart!" or "Why? Why is this happening to me?" Granted, it doesn't help that there is hardly a decent actor in this film, but the bad script and even worse directing of the actors gives them very little to work with. Everybody seems to be going through a mood swing every two lines, and displays at least 10 different states of mind over the course of the film. Characters constantly contradict themselves or seem to have an extremely short-term memory. If there is one positive thing I can say about this movie, it is that the only things sillier than the acting and dialogues are the cheesy lyrics to the songs that accompany the gratuitious and protracted sex scenes (such as the text "you are my rose" endlessly repeated).The only job where Wiseau fails even worse than as a writer or director is as an actor. The cult value of his portrayal cannot be overstated. He almost looks and sounds like a heavily drugged and sedated combination of Gru from Despicable Me with Loki from Thor, who is trying to impersonate Pauly Shore. It has to be seen to be believed. His final scene and the movie's finale is the stuff of talentless overacting legends. If you haven't rolled off the couch by then, you'll never will.In conclusion, it is quite irrelevant to say that as a film, The Room makes every mistake in the book and is the most unlikely culmination of bad decisions that may have ever been made, since this is exactly the reason for what makes it so alluring. You can have discussions about guilty pleasures, but as long as there is no concensus on what constitutes great art, those won't be very meaningful. If cabinets made from wreckage and dresses made from meat can be forms of art, why not this dubious cinematographic experiment? Something so uniquely bad comes by only once in a generation. So is The Room a good movie? Not by a long shot. Does it make for interesting art? That's the idea.

reviews.review_title: Unbelievable it was made, but it became a cult movie.
reviews.content: This movie is both horrible, naive and surreal. Anyway, it's unbelievable that it was done. One fact, however, deserves mention: in all disgrace, with his perseverance of Don Quixote and flamboyant and pathetic personality, Tommy Wiseau has managed to make his film, put his name on the records of the film industry. And for God's sake, the movie became Cult.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as it could have been
reviews.content: There seems to be a lot of people proposing that The Room is "the worst movie of all time". A better epithet might be "the most unintentionally funny movie of all time". The acting is terrible and the story isn't particularly good, but the camera work seems OK to me and some of the roof shots are kind of interesting. There are long stretches in the movie which aren't bad enough to be remarkable. A lot of this is just boring. I'm guessing that the circumstances surrounding the production and the cult-like fans are adding to the public conception of the movie. Realistically a movie should be judged on the content alone, and by that standard there must be many movies worse than The Room.

reviews.review_title: Tommy Wiseau THE MAN, THE MYTH, THE LEGEND.
reviews.content: I can't believe what I just saw, and I can't wait to watch someone watching The room for the first time. The most appropriate part in this whole masterpiece is the first thirty seconds of the opening credits. Ladies and gentlemen, here is the film that challenged all the foundations of cinema and will stand the test of time.This piece is concluded with one of the most heartbreaking quotes that I've seen. "I've lost him, but I still have you, right? Right? Mark".

With the soon to be released 'The Disaster Artist', I figured I would finally watch this movie. It's definitely something else. I didn't really laugh out loud at any point but it's quite amusing throughout. The dialogue comes across as starting a script in English then translating it to another language and then back to English. People blurt out dialogue in scenes like they've been coached to say it as quickly as possible. Tommy Wiseau dialogue seems like it has been dubbed throughout as it goes in and out of sync.The plot is non-existent and scenes don't seem to serve a plot they're just there. People come over to the apartment and then leave at the end of their scene which is usually 2 minutes after they arrive. Performances range from terrible to passable. Greg Sestero who plays Mark appears beleaguered throughout which is probably not acting but more the amount of work he was doing behind the scenes.All in all it's worth seeing to prepare to see the dramatized making of movie 'the Disaster Artist. It is a fascinating movie that only exists because a man had money and a vision so weird you can't look away.

When Mark Kermode was reviewing the ludicrous Nic Cage sci-fi thriller 'Knowing' for BBC Radio 5 Live, the show's substitute presenter declared it to be "the worst film I've ever seen", to which Kermode replied "Believe me, 'Knowing' is not one of the worst films ever. That just tells me you haven't seen enough really terrible films." You might think you have seen a truly atrocious film; but if you've yet to see Tommy Wiseau's infamous melodrama 'The Room', you haven't. Believe me. This is indeed one of those bad movies. One that is so staggeringly awful that it becomes something highly entertaining. Retrospectively, writer/director/producer/actor Tommy Wiseau has asserted that the film was intended to be "a black comedy", but conversely, numerous cast members have objected, outlining that it was unintentionally bad. Frankly, it's hard to tell.Put simply, 'The Room' is a movie about a guy whose fiancée is cheating on him with his best friend, but like Pandora's Box it is so much more than that – it is a film that is bad in virtually every aspect. The script (was there even one?) flows terribly and features multiple inconsistencies (characters and seemingly important plot strands disappear for no reason) and countless things that just don't make any sense (for example, the character of Denny or a conversation about banking where the protagonist played by Wiseau randomly asks his friend "So how's your sex life?") The score is nauseatingly bad. The various sex scenes are tediously pointless and beyond cringeworthy. The acting is unanimously terrible. With his accent that sounds like a queasy concoction of Schwarzenegger and Borat doing a shoddy Christopher Walken impersonation, Tommy Wiseau is a fascinating presence to watch on screen, albeit because of his apparent lack of any sort of acting talent. Yet, despite this he has crafted something that no one else has arguably done – he has made the worst film of the 21st century thus far. "The Citzen Kane of bad movies", Entertainment Weekly called it; Variety proclaimed that it "prompts most of its viewers to ask for their money back – before even 30 minutes have passed"; or comedy writer Robert Popper's comment that "every scene is perfectly bad." These statements might sound over-the- top if you haven't seen it, but if you have then you know that they do indeed ring true and could even be considered understatements.Over the years, 'The Room' has developed a cult following, with multiple fan screenings around the world and a fanbase that includes Jonah Hill, Kristen Stewart, Edgar Wright and Kristen Bell. None of this is particularly surprising, because it is one of the most purely entertaining movies I've seen; it is truly terrible, but so incomprehensibly so that it never fails to put a smile on my face or make me howl with laughter. It has to be seen to be believed and if you've seen it already, watch it again.

reviews.review_title: A movie so bad that it's aged perfectly
reviews.content: Who knew merely 20 years later people would still be enjoying this film because of the absurdity and it's real attempt to be a serious film. Hilarious, but if I have to rate it in terms of an actual movie's standard, it's a definite 1.

I simply couldn't keep my comments in my pocket any longer. "The Room" is an expertly crafted "black" comedy by an idiosyncratic filmmaker, but it's also much more than that.Producer/writer/director/star Tommy Wiseau somehow managed to achieve the impossible with "The Room". Besides delivering a knee-slapping chucklefest for discriminating purveyors of alternative-style humor like myself (and my future wife, who watched it with me), this cinematic gem is also a thinly veiled love letter from Mr. Wiseau to all the ladies of the world. This is most evident by all the time "Johnny" dedicates to keeping "Lisa" satisfied in "The Room". The prowess he displays in the bedroom is staggering. My future wife played it off, but she noticed. I mean, how could I blame her? Just take that trademark slow-but-steady thrust Johnny delivers to Lisa's abdominal region on numerous occasions. Or how his arm stays flexed when he's spooning with her, even when he's sound asleep. Johnny hasn't even gotten started before he sets pulses racing by giving female viewers an ample opportunity to steal a glimpse of his beautiful buttocks.I had to change me underwears four times the night we viewed this film, so it's alright by me that a guy who made me laugh THAT much captured my future wife's imagination while I was away washing up. But keep in mind...I just like to watch.

reviews.review_title: Warning: watching THE ROOM may be hazardous to your brain cells.
reviews.content: I first heard about THE ROOM from an article from Entertainment Weekly detailing how it went from being a cheaply made horrible film to a cult classic. Now I've seen my share of cult films that started out as bombs at the box office, but now that I've actually seen the movie, I can't get over who awful it really is. Whe they said it's a really, REALLY bad film, they were not kidding. Did Tommy Wiseau wake up one day and decide to make a film? Sure looks that way. The badness is beyond comprehension.1) Let's get this out of the way: Regardless of what Johnny, Mark, or any guy in the movie says, Lisa is not sexy/beautiful/hot, etc. She's not ugly by any means, but she looks more like a plain Jane posing for a Lane Bryant catalog. 2) The first scene with Johnny and Lisa going upstairs about to get intimate---and Denny follows them? WTF? This is supposedly a kid and he wants to watch his, uh, what exactly ARE Johnny and Lisa in relation to Denny? Adoptive parents? Guardians? Babysitters? Whatever, why is Denny not getting the hint that Johnny and Lisa want to be ALONE? No wonder he turns to drugs. Or maybe, like Johnny tells Mark later on, he should get a girl. 3) Story lines that come and go without any resolution, like Claudette's breast cancer or Denny's run-in with a dude with a gun asking about his money.4) Characters that are not properly introduced, like the couple that decide to stop by Johnny and Lisa's apartment to feed each other chocolate. Or the therapist that seems to give lame advice to Johnny and is a chicken for not wanting to play Toss The Football. Or that other guy that catches Lisa and Mark getting cozy at Johnny's birthday party. 5) What's with calling someone that doesn't want to do something chicken and going cheep-cheep-cheep-cheep? I expect this behavior from grade school kids, not grown men and whatever Denny is suppose to be.6) Chocolate is NOT a symbol of love. And eating chocolate from a woman's neck is NOT romantic. It's gross. 7) You really see how badly edited this film is from watching the scene when Lisa is holding/not holding a wine glass. 8) Is Lisa's neck pregnant? WTF IS THAT??? 9) So Wiseau manages to get beautiful shots of San Francisco, but when it comes to the rooftop scenes, he uses greenscreen? 10) Headscratching lines like:"Leave you stupid comments in your pocket." "What kind of money?" and the unromantic "Chocolate is a symbol of love." 11) The scene in the coffee shop looked like the cameraperson left the camera running on the counter in the middle of lunch hour. 12) Love scenes that are more useful to promote abstinence than to entertain anyone.13) Start a drinking game for every time someone says "Don't worry about it." "I don't want to talk about it." or "Oh hi {insert name here}." 14) Lisa orders the weirdest pizza topping combo I've ever heard of (half Canadian bacon with pineapple, half artichoke with pesto, and light on the cheese), only to end up with a plain cheese pizza. 15) Is Wiseau allergic to the word fiancée? He constantly uses "future wife" or "future husband", which sounds really strange. 16) Mark tells a story about a girl he knew that had way too many boyfriends, one finds out about the others and beats the girl up, and Johnny finds the story funny? Seriously??? 17) Johnny and Mark running up a bunch of stairs in San Franciso, playing tackle in the park, and we can barely hear what they're saying. At least, I can't make out what they're saying. 18) I understand getting angry after finding out your fiancée--- excuse me, future wife cheats on you, but that was the worst wrecking-the-apartment moment I've ever seen. Even rock stars on drugs do a better job wrecking their hotel rooms. 19) The only credible actor in this whole film is the pug. "Hi, doggie." 20) Finding Johnny dead in a pool of blood and NO ONE thinks to call the police nor an ambulance? They just sit there and cry? What, they think their tears will resurrect poor Johnny? If they ever make a sequel (let's pray they don't), those will be some incredible wonder tear powers.

reviews.review_title: My favorite "so bad it's good" movie
reviews.content: The extra star is for it's unintentional entertainment value. And yes, it was not supposed to be a "black comedy" as Tommy Wiseau would like you to now believe. Actors have confirmed that this was, indeed, supposed to be a very serious film.To describe its plot would be pointless, because that is not the draw of the film. The terrible line delivery, poor green screen effects, godawful voice dubbing, bad editing, and overall dreadful writing all collide to create the perfect storm.So, please, watch this movie. I have seen it many times, and it still has me rolling on the floor. I've never attended a screening of this movie, but from what I hear, the audience yells lines at the screen that I would imagine would ruin the hilarity of it if you watch it in that atmosphere without seeing it beforehand. Anyway, fun and funny movie.

reviews.review_title: A must see for film students
reviews.content: Cinematographic masterpiece. So Johnny is just your Joe average likeable guy (with the voice of a star wars character) who's got it all. A pretty wife (Lisa), a best friend (Mark), and a unique young friend (Danny) who tries to join Johnny and Lisa in bed, and gets involved with shady drug deals. Together they take on the world.. and over an hour of your precious time.

reviews.review_title: 1/10 but also one of the most entertaining films
reviews.content: This is a 1/10 simply because I can't seriously give it anything else. That doesn't mean I didn't enjoy this movie however! I have very really laughed so much at a screwball comedy let alone a movie labeled as a romantic drama. Every single scene had me in stitches. Tommy Wiseau is either the worst filmmaker ever or secretly the comedic genius the world needed. I prefer the former as him genuinely thinking this movie was going to be great makes the movie a whole other level of funny. Trust me you want to watch this movie it is an experience you won't have with any other movie. So bad it's actually amazing!

reviews.review_title: This film is tearing me apart!
reviews.content: I became aware of The Room after reading reviews for Birdemic, comparing two bad films. So I had to sit down and watch The Room to see for myself, which I did with no preconceptions about it other than a few vague references to it being a bad movie.I won't say it's the worst film ever made, since I believe that (dis)honor goes to Birdemic in my opinion. While The Room had atrocious acting, a lousy plot, and poor dialog, it at least had decent editing and good sound although if I see one more panning shot of San Francisco I think I'm going to vomit.Several things which brought this film down were the aforementioned poor acting (whoever told Tommy Wiseau that he could act needs to be slapped senseless), lousy dialog, and poor plot. There was only one or two decent actors in the whole film.The character of Denny was just annoying. I mean, he's 18, not 8 for goodness' sakes, why does he want to throw the football around all the time? Speaking of which, the one football toss scene where the actors kept running into and out of the scene reminded me of a Saturday Night Live skit.The use of green screen in the rooftop scenes was pretty noticeable, partially because the actors hair didn't blow in the wind. This wasn't particularly annoying though.There was nothing lovable about the character of Johnny which made you want to like him. The way he acted didn't give off any feeling of warmth, so why was everyone so concerned about his feelings? There also could have been a couple of good subplot with Denny & the drug dealer, but once that conflict was over, it was never mentioned again, nor did they ever figure out why he was buying drugs anyway. Same with Lisa's mother telling her about having breast cancer, almost in passing. But once that scene was over, nothing else was ever said. It's like those parts of the movie were just thrown in for the heck of it. The fight scenes were totally unrealistic (as was everything else) and near the end when Johnny was going on his "rampage" was pretty laughable. Basically the whole movie was worse that a Lifetime made-for-TV movie, with basically the same plot. Even as a so-bad-it's-good type of movie, this one doesn't even make me want to laugh at it.

If we had to choose the king of trash movies, that title would probably go to The Room. It's so horrible you can't help but love it. And just wait till you hear some background information! Tommy Wiseau apparently financed this movie by selling leather jackets imported from Korea. An actor decided to leave the crew while filming, so they picked another person to finish shooting his scenes; because of that, we have two completely different people playing the same character. Doesn't this sound promising? The Room tells us about the life of Johnny (Tommy Wiseau), a successful banker who lives with his soon-to-be wife Lisa (Juliette Danielle), has many friends and is loved by everyone. Unfortunately, his girlfriend doesn't love him any more and is having an affair with his best friend Mark (Greg Sestero), who is constantly battled between his desire to be with Lisa and not wanting to hurt Johnny.Everybody agrees that nothing about this movie works. The story is recycled, the acting is bad and the cinematography is not worth mentioning. Certain scenes and characters are put into the movie for no apparent reason, except for making it last longer. The dialogue is repetitive and predictable. I guess you're supposed to sympathise with Johnny, because he's such a good, naive person being betrayed by the two people he loves the most – but you don't, because all the feelings in this movie are just words. But, after you get over the first minutes of confusion in the beginning, The Room is guaranteed to make you laugh really hard.Besides, this movie is a cult. Who could possibly forget the roof scene, in which Johnny talks to himself and later realises Mark is also present? The famous phrase "oh hi Mark" is used in this scene. Or all those inexplicable random football tossings, that once happened while the characters were in tuxedos? And of course, the flower shop, one of the most confusingly useless scenes in movie history. All this can be pretty frustrating to watch, but you shouldn't take it too seriously. If you don't, at the end you might even want to see it again sometime, maybe just to have a few good laughs and to remind yourself that it can always be worse – you could have been born as Tommy Wiseau! Rating:2/10 Read more at http://passpopcorn.wordpress.com/

reviews.review_title: A masterpiece of trash film making
reviews.content: The story of 'The Room' can honestly be inspirational. Tommy Wiseau was a nobody before this film and now we all quote his lines from this disaster. I have never reviewed such a film, a film that is filled with horrible acting, editing, lighting or special effects yet for some reason is so great. Of course the pure stupidity of this film was never intentional which is why it is so hilarious. Wiseau intended this to be a breakthrough motion picture, the film that would catapult him to the top of the food chain in Hollywood. This attitude can be seen when you watch 'The Room'. It is very easy to spot the indulgence of the film maker, he gives it his all in the film. Don't get me wrong, his performance is truly terrible but he is still trying so hard which in a lot of ways I admire. The film went through horrible production issues, many of the crew members abandoned the project and Wiseau had to find replacements. I admire that he continued and finished the picture even with everyone against him. The film offers some of the hardest laughs I have ever seen in a film, I laughed more frequent than even in some of the better comedies. This is absolutely a remarkable picture that I believe should be seen by everyone. Especially that we are now getting the behind the scenes story of this film in this year's 'The Disaster Artist'. In summary, I do not think that 'The Room' is good movie, it's the exact opposite but what makes the film so great is the fact that they were trying so hard to make a good movie. Wiseau wanted to make a thought provoking and dramatic picture, but it turned out to be a perfect example of a disastrous piece of art.

reviews.review_title: 1/10 for the film, 10/10 for the experience
reviews.content: To be quite frank, the screening I attended of this film at Central Michigan was one of the most memorable and flat out fun times I have been to the movies. I had heard about The Room years before I actually saw it, watching the Nostalgia Critic's review of the film and also viewing Cinema Sins' take on the movie. Since it is so infamous, when I saw the poster for the screening, I instantly knew I would have to attend. Unbeknownst to myself and the friend that I was with, the film's following is devote just like the following for The Rocky Horror Picture Show. At the screening, fans had showed up in suits, were throwing a football around, chucking spoons and other plastic cutlery at the screen, and repeating lines of dialogue along with the film. It was an absolute blast and the only to see this cult classic. The film itself is terrible, but at this point, it doesn't really matter. I was laughing so hard I was crying during this movie, along with the rest of the audience. The experience is definitely worth the film itself!

reviews.review_title: Terrible movie, but funny as hell
reviews.content: This movie is the prime example of "so bad it's good" movie. It fails in every possible level so badly, that it becomes incredibly funny. This movie is bad, bad, bad, bad, bad. So bad, that it becomes a gigantic joke. And Mr. Wiseau is riding in the top of it.The plot? (spoiler alert) a cyborg called Johnny works in a bank, but his girlfriend, Lisa, cheats on him with his "best friend" Mark. Why?, because "Lisa is so beautiful", and "she doesn't love Johnny anymore". Yep, those are all the reasons we got. In fact the lines "Lisa is so beautiful", "Johnny/Mark is my best friend" and "I don't love Johnny anymore" are repeated over and over again. I think Mr. Wiseau was worried with viewers forgetting those important plot points. So, at the end, Johnny finds out everything in his birthday party, and he kills himself after destroying a room. Yep, pretty lame.But, from this lame plot as the seed, a mighty tree of awfulness grows. The dialog is stupid beyond belief: repetitive, with scenes thrown at random and other scenes almost duplicated point by point. The acting is awful, and subplots and characters are introduced and then dropped immediately. And, the cherry of the cake are Tommy Wiseau's "acting" skills... which are so hilariously bad, it's incredible, a must-see.So, as a movie, this thing is a failure of epic proportions. As a piece of unintentional entertainment, is the best thing ever made.1/10

reviews.review_title: So bad you have to see it to appreciate it's greatness.
reviews.content: The Room is an incoherent mess full of unconvincing acting and lousy writing.....And that's what make's it amazing. This film is astonishingly bad. Despite Tommy Wisseau's assertions that this film was created as a black comedy this film was actually intended to be a tragic story of betrayal. The fact that this film is as bad as it is without trying to be bad actually make's this film one big joke.If you can enjoy a film that's so bad it's good then give this movie a watch; you won't regret it. I actually had to take breaks between the scenes because I was laughing so hard at how awful it was.Give it a watch and enjoy this jewel of a film; you'll be spouting lines from the film in no time.

I only need to say two words: TOMMY WISEAU. He really might be the best director, producer, writer, and actor of all time. Dude can do it all. Dude wrote some of the best characters we've ever seen in film. Mark, Denny, Chris R, Peter, Lisa, Lisa's Mom, the list keeps going on. 10/10 go watch it if you haven't.

reviews.review_title: Bad but bad you can appreciate
reviews.content: The room is bad. Very bad. But under all the the bad their is hart. It's a mans vision, one mans vision and he did it.. he did it. He made a movie. How many of us have made a film. Exactly.. he made a movie and it's a movie. Hats off to the guy who had a dream. A dream to make a moveie and throw a football around. And then to make that movie...and throw a football around...while speaking words. And to ride that movie till the wheels fell off..good luck to tommy.

Many Indie films are overlooked for many reasons. Down-to-earth plots, non A-list actors, and avant-garde visuals. In retrospect, Tommy Wiseau's "The Room" is an indie film that is overlooked for all the "right reasons". It's a black comedy romance, that revolves around a love traingle between Johnny (Tommy Wiseau), Lisa (Juliette Danielle), and Johnny's best friend Mark (Greg Sestero). The overall narrative is confusing with several subplots juggling around at the same time. Any movie-goer (even little kids) could point out all the plot holes and visual errors of this 90 min film. The characters are all from the stockpile of any movie cliché one can think of. The dialogue is beyond the horribleness of a George Lucas (not to mention that most of Tommy Wiseau's dialogue is dubbed). Nothing is subtle in this film, any moment of awkwardness sticks out like a sore thumb. Despite these numerous faults, "The Room" is probably the most entertaining film ever made. I wouldn't be lying if I said I would watch this film over and over again and still laughing at Tommy Wiseau's odd delivery of lines and the awkward "filler scenes" that flushes away some of the drama. Tommy Wiseau may be one of the worst filmmakers in history. However, he should also be credited as one of the most important filmmakers who revitalized the cult followings of other independent films overlooked by the mainstream audiences and critics.
This is by far the best movie I have seen in my life. I would recommend watching it!

The movie is so geniously bad, i would have a bad Time discribing the plot.
So this Guy Johnny, true american hero, he had everything, good looks, good job and many friends. And this girl, his fiancé she betray him! And this Johnny, he go crazy, decides to kill himself infront of the World to see. And maybe Johnny is Vampire.Ok, that was from the Disaster Artist, a movie about a bad movie.I love it...

reviews.review_title: This Really Is The Citizen Kane Of Bad Movies!
reviews.content: I love movies! I really do, and I am willing to watch almost anything because I believe even the worst films have at least one good thing about them. This film has nothing good in it. Nothing! This particular gem of awfulness was written, produced, and directed by a guy named Tommy Wiseau. He was also the main actor. No one knows where he's from (I think he's Eastern European), but he is such a terrible actor. Every line of dialog he speaks is emotionless, boring, and has this very snooty feeling about it. That's not even the worst part. He can't enunciate his words correctly. Not a single phrase is spoken correctly. It's so bad that it's actually funny. The film is about a guy named Johnny, who works at a bank and lives in an apartment in San Francisco. He lives with his fiancée Lisa, has a best friend named Mark, and a high school/college student named Denny who is is admirer. We never see Johnny at his job; we just see him play football in a tuxedo, and make passionate love with Lisa. However, Lisa becomes bored with him (how does that happen), and she cheats on him with...you guessed it, Mark. I think Wiseau was trying to make a drama about cheating and the negative effects of it, but the film plot is so full of holes that you won't even know what's happening half the time. At least the plot's slightly better than Uwe Boll's films, but that's not saying much. Ultimately, even though I hate this film with a passion, I recommend that people go out and watch it. It's really interesting to see how this project went so bad, and it stands as a lesson to those who want to make movies. It's not as easy as it seems. Even though it's one of the worst films of all time, I recommend that you see it at least once. You'll thank me later. Final Verdict: 1/10* Recommend you see it at least once.

I watched The Room because of the hype surrounding it since The Disaster Artist was released. I was told going in that it was a terrible movie, but I should still watch it. While some people found how bad the movie is funny, I did not. I felt like I wasted my time watching this movie. I still would have never watched it if the Disaster Artist hadn't been nominated for an Oscar. I am told that if you watch this in the right atmosphere and with the right people, it can be quite an enjoyable watch. This was not the case for me. I am happy to say I watched it, I can understand what people are talking about now, but I wish they would talk about other movies.

When someone calls a film "terrible", they're usually either exaggerating or have no concept of what a terrible film truly is. The Room embodies that concept. It's not just poorly written, poorly acted, poorly directed - poorly everything - it honestly looks like a bad student film. But what makes it great is not just that the film-maker Tommy Wiseau is completely incompetent, but that he somehow managed to spend millions of dollars on the production and it still turned out like it did. Although it's truly an awful film, it's so entertaining to watch. You are laughing at the film and at the actors, but most the them now have a good sense of humour about it. Even if you're not into cult films or low-budget films or watching films because they're bad, you can enjoy The Room. It honestly has to be seen to be believed. On entertainment value, I could give it 10 stars, but realistically, this is the film that 1/10 was created for.

You know in the American knock-off movie Dinner for Schmucks, when Steve Carell's character is showing the dead mice in little dioramas and explaining them in hilariously incorrect ways? That's how this movie is. You can't believe he can do it and keep it up, but sure enough, he does! I would watch this movie once a week except every time I mention it, my wife becomes enraged. It's so complexly layered with fibers of feces that you have to rewind and replay each few minutes (except the sex scenes, which replay themselves) to catch all the nuances.My voice is hoarse from shouting "What the hell?!" over and over. The screenplay seems to be a Mad-lib filled in by patients in an asylum. You can stare at Wiseau's face for minutes on end and still not understand how it is connected together. It's like his makeup artist is M.C. Escher.About a minute into the movie, I get the giggles and they don't stop except when the confusion/badness/outrageousness level gets so high that I have to vent by begging for some sort of explanation.Everything about it is perfect. The sincerity mixed with incompetence. The abject pathos of the autobiographical message mated with the apparently huge ego of the subject. The ambition compared to the final "output." As each moment is added to the pile, the silliness increases.It's as if you're at a wedding and a bridesmaid has her skirt tucked into her underwear. It gets funnier and funnier the longer it goes on. And then someone farts. And you are trying so hard not to make any sound because the preacher is talking and he says "We are gathered her to salivate this holy headlock." Then the candles catch the bride's veil on fire. And then when they try to put the fire out, the bride starts doing push-ups. It's as if each event is more impossible than the last and there's no explanation, and all the while, you get this sense that someone went to the trouble of making it just like this because that's how he wanted it to be! It truly is like sitting on an atomic bomb that's about to explode.

reviews.review_title: A Tale That Will Make You Laugh, Cry, and then Feel Shame
reviews.content: What can be said about The Room that hasn't already been said?It is considered by many to be one of the worst films ever made.It's poorly acted, it's poorly paced, the plot is confusing, entire plot threads are dropped at a moments notice.They play football for no reason, they wear tuxedos for no reason. One minute Lisa is in love with Johnny, suddenly she can't stand him. One minute Mark is sleeping with Lisa, the next he's getting upset that someone would even suggest he'd sleep with his best friends fiancé. The best over-reaction from Mark comes when Peter asks him flat out if he's sleeping with Lisa, and Mark attempts to kill Peter by throwing him off the roof. Just out of the blue the guy is ready to commit murder just because someone asked him if he was doing what he's been doing.The stand out role in this film is Denny. Denny is the creepy college kid who lives next door, who likes to just let himself into Johnny and Lisa's bedroom because "he likes to watch."For all of this film's flaws (which are countless), I have to say that I love this movie.It is the purest example ever made of a film that is so bad that it is good. It's one of the funniest movies I've ever seen. The sad part is, that none of it is supposed to be funny. But it just is. The love scenes, the scenes where Johnny flips out and kicks Lisa out, Johnny and Mark just talking about random things (it really is random, one minute they are talking about Johnny's client, suddenly "How's your sex life?").The best part of the movie is when Johnny kills himself. The icing on the cake of that scene is as Mark suddenly turns on Lisa and dumps her, Denny wants to be left alone with the body. And as creepy as Denny is, one can only imagine what Denny plans to do.I know people will see the 10 I gave this and think, "What is wrong with this guy?" But I can't help it. If I thoroughly enjoy a film, I'm going to give it a perfect score, no matter what it's flaws. Because I rate based on how much I enjoyed sitting through a movie, and how willing I am to sit through it multiple times. And this is one of those movies. It's so bad, that it's become a legend.Check it out if you haven't seen it.

reviews.review_title: You will NOT believe THIS!!! A MUST SEE!
reviews.content: Wow! Just to be fair, I'm rating this movie as 'awful', because it is definitely the worst movie I've ever seen in my entire life! HOWEVER, I never had more fun with a movie rated 10 stars! Also, I've seen it more than 3 times by the time I write this review. That means something.This movie is really AWSFUL and the absolute proof that aliens exist!Because you HAVE to be an alien to: 1) be able to claim you're an American and yet speak with such an out-of-this-world Transyl-Bulgarian accent from Mars. 2) to actually open every scene with "Oh hi, (name of the character)". 3) to have the guts to show your naked body ON SCREEN after having it 'improved' by a delirious intern experimenting with botox. 4) have a talent to cast the worst actors and / or give the worst stage directions in history. 5) To remain faithful to the illusion that you have created a masterpiece for the rest of your life after all these horrible reviews AND to be convinced that only truly intelligent viewers could appreciate your work and that people could actually learn a lot from you. They should, just once, offer an Oscar for 'worst all-in-one film creator EVER'! Seeing how ONE SINGLE movie can be SO BAD in SO MANY different respects is mind blowing!This man has a TALENT! 1) Even if you tried REALLY HARD you could never be a worse actor than him. 2) Even the worst director could never willingly make a movie this crappy. 3) If a dog, just ran over by a truck, would try to bark together a script it would be better than this. This movie is awful, hilarious and un-be-lie-va-ble at the same time. Also, it's very very very SAD. It's obvious Tommy Wiseau wants you to feel for his character. He wants you to think Lisa is a bitch for leaving him, while actually you don't understand why any woman in her right mind would fall for a guy like that! He wants you to think his character is the most wonderful guy in the world! After all, he brings her flowers, takes care of a lonely boy, is not angry when people have sex in his apartment for no reason, etc. Even 'the mother-in-law' approves of him! He wants you to cry at the end when he commits suicide... but actually all you feel is: "Go shoot yourself you big whiner!" The only thing you're sorry about is that it took so long. This movie is obviously intended to be a drama but that's actually the last thing it is. It's not even a movie! At most, it's a documentary about a bunch of weird people trying to make one. The conversations are unnatural, the situations are bizarre, out of this world even. The choice of music (especially during the sex scenes - who asked for them anyway?!) is terrible! (You are my rose, you are my rose, you are my rose...)In drama class we used to practise our lines by throwing a ball at each other while saying them out loud. This guy actually uses this exercise in a scene several times! Hilarious! He probably read in a book on narratology that it's good to have your characters do something during a scene. :-) Imagine what would happen if Tommy Wiseau read a book on surgery!"Anyway how's your sex life?"Maybe Tommy Wiseau should study human behaviour in stead of 'Explaining it all on YouTube'. He'd notice people don't just say: "I'm so happy to have you as my best friend and I love Lisa so much"... out of the blue.Really dude: "Show me don't tell me!"Anyway... I sooo recommend this 'documentary'! DO watch it, preferably with friends and preferably over and over again. You'll roll on the floor!

reviews.review_title: The Best Worst Movie I've Ever Seen
reviews.content: This movie steals a place in my heart. It had awful plot and awful acting but it was so damn entertaining considering I watched till the end. Honestly if they upgraded the cast I would've fell asleep the first 20 minutes and forgot about this film; this cast was one of a kind. The best part was I felt unworthy to watch any superb Oscar worthy performances like I wasn't worthy lol.Movie-wise 0/10; entertainment-wise 9/10

reviews.review_title: The voice of innocence whispers in our ears...
reviews.content: Is it really possible that this luminous masterpiece is a first feature film? It is as though Mozart had started his career in composition with one of his mature symphonies. What is totally special about 'The Room' is the visual control that Tommy Wiseau applies to the story, and his use of fabulous music to embed his amazing images in our mind. The 'Talented Mr. Ripley'-ish story could have been turgid, but Wiseau turns it into a mythic journey.At the heart of Wiseau's method is the fabulous use of repetition in his work with the character Greg. "What's going on here?". This has been characteristic of each of Wiseau's films. Here it totally sucks the viewer into the story and is just about, the high-point of 2000s cinema. Alongside this, Wiseau uses some of the most haunting music in existence. Whether it is Kitra Williams or Clint Jun Gamboa, Wiseau transports us with fabulous romantic imagery that perfectly balances it.I started on this comment determined not to use the word 'poetry', but I just can't avoid it. With nearly all filmmakers, including very great ones, the style that they present is very much prose - great prose, perhaps, but firmly rooted on the ground. With Wiseau, we are taken, emotionally, to the stars by the lyric magnificence of the totality of his vision.It is said that Welles learned cinema by watching John Ford's 'Stagecoach' before embarking on 'Citizen Kane'. Every young filmmaker should watch this amazing masterpiece again and again and again and inform their work with Wiseau's matchless sense of true cinema.

reviews.review_title: Today's lesson: bad movie, fun audience
reviews.content: This is a case where the movie is just awful. Nothing good can be said by a sensible intelligent person about this film, period. That said, what the 10 star young people seem to rave about is the "experience" part of the screening. As "Rocky Horror" did years ago, "The Room" has created a cult following of young people (mostly) who go to the film to make fun of the corny dialogue and silly premises. As with any "experience" film, the fun is that most of the audience has already seen the movie. They shout out the dialogue and give appropriate groans when the dialogue is exceptionally bad (which is almost always the case). If that is what you crave - a social interactive film experience - then "The Room" is your kind of movie. It has nothing else to offer... really. It is not an independent classic. It is not the great insight of a film genius. It is not the latest trend in cinema (although it closely resembles aspects of reality television). And, it is not a good movie. It is a very, very bad movie. But the experience is fun. Thus ended the lesson.

reviews.review_title: A great experience with an awful film
reviews.content: This is seriously the worst movie of all time; there really is no contest here. The acting, the use of shots, the music and the overall premise is unbelievably bad. A love triangle between a banker, a hunk and a blonde woman is the plot of this film which has been likened to a play by the director, Tommy Wiseau. Unfortunately this same guy is the producer and writer. Oh, and he stars in it too.Do not go into this movie expecting the best romance ever made or even a decent romance for that matter. No matter how much potential each actor/actress holds, they all share the same emotionless line reading status. The main star of this film (and I guess rightly so because of how awesome he looks) is Tommy Wiseau who plays Johnny, a banker and lover. It is fair to say without insulting anyone that his accent alone makes the movie. His pronunciation of words and sentences has become standout moments in their own sense. Accompanying him and the other range of characters is a green screen backdrop overlooking a very bland looking city. Despite being called 'The Room', the apartment and the roof play big parts in this movie themselves.One of the worst things about this movie is the music throughout it. Despite the movie being a romantic drama, the dramatic piano theme that would be much better suited to a TV movie about hobbits, keeps coming back to annoy us viewers throughout various points in the movie. In the opening it works quite well and sets the scene but then it gets boring very quickly and it is ridiculously overused. If I see this next time then I will be tempted to start a drinking game involving the times this theme appears in the movie! The music is so laughably bad in parts of the movie (and by parts I mean the whole thing) that this makes the movie more laughable than it already is. For example, music suddenly plays when one of the characters, Greg, enters the room and then suddenly stops. This is only one of the many instances when dramatic music is used out of nowhere for no apparently reason! When it's not cheap instrumental music, it's instead cheesy lyrical love songs that play during the clichéd sex scenes.Another funny thing in this movie is the tendency to bring up random story lines and then get rid of them soon after. There is a breast cancer line spoken by the mother which is never referred to again in the rest of the movie. We are aware that it is a movie about love and not cancer, but if there's not going to be a resolution then don't bring it up to begin with. Another storyline that had a lot of potential to interest us viewers above the main storyline was Denny's drug money problems. A random thug appears on the infamous rooftop where he threatens Denny with a gun however after a commotion this is never talked about again. And what's with the couple who feel the need to make love in Johnny's apartment before Lisa and her mother arrive?This brings us to another problem in the movie. Many unimportant elements such as the random couple are focused on too much in this movie. The movie focuses on the couple's attempt at love-making for a few minutes which made me think that perhaps these are two other important characters in what could be a separate plot. But nope. They are just simply secondary characters who are never really focused on again; meaning the need to show them at all is simply pointless. In a café scene, we are forced to sit through the orders of four random customers before Johnny comes into the scene! What is the point? Add to this the countless establishing shots in between more important scenes and it's fair to say this movie focuses too much on what shouldn't be focused on.This review could go on forever because there is a lot to say about this movie. And none of it is positive. However negative this review may seem though, this movie has actually given me one of the most joyful movie-going experiences in my life. I would pay over and over again just to see this movie. It is full of unintentional laughs because of its bad direction, terrible acting thanks to our star Tommy Wiseau and the unforgettable music. And for that, I want to thank Tommy for giving us a perfect example of not only everything a movie should never be; a good lesson to filmmakers and audiences alike, but also for giving us one of the best unintentional comedies of all time. I recommend this movie for a good time, and a good time only. Definitely a movie worth paying for if it is playing in your city.
This is beyond astonishing. One of the best movies of all time. Tommy Wiseau gives us a magnificent performance, worthy of an Oscar. I cannot understand why people hate this masterpiece so much.

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies I have ever seen
reviews.content: I see a lot of people giving this movie good reviews and feel justice has to be done to this crap.  This is the first movie I have ever walked out of in my life.  I don't know if this movie is meant as a joke or what.  Roger Ebert even gave this a good review.  I think he is a smart critic but I don't know.  Maybe this one was funded by Disney.  This is possibly the worst movie I have ever seen in a theater.  The acting is like one of those Cinemax soft core porn movies except with less people taking off their clothes (not much less).  This movie is actually hilarious I think unintentionally.  How anyone could like this is beyond me.  6.9 rating ? This movie has a higher rating than a lot of good movies.  Unbelievable! This should be down there with Gigli and Manos Hands  of Time like 1.5 !

reviews.review_title: Great movie, new ideas, black comedy.
reviews.content: This is very good film. I like everything about it: acting,directing, script and design. Tommy Wiseau delivered the role of his life. I was never bored at all watching it. It makes you think. The directing is extraordinary. And the ending to this film is surprising and scary. I give this 10 our of 10. Highly recommended.

The Room - Wow. This movie was wrong on so many levels! Lets start with the acting. Sometimes, er, often, the acting didn't match the script! They would say one thing, but either have no emotion or the wrong emotion! The way Lisa acted, it was really unclear that she was a total lunatic. The way Johnny acted, SPOILER ALERT, I didn't think he cared enough about Lisa that he'd be distraught when she left. Sure, in the script he said it - but the actor never sold it. About that script - "Don't worry about it!" A little in joke because at one point Lisa's mom says she has breast cancer, and Lisa says "Don't worry about it." So they don't - they never mention it again! This plays right into the wheelhouse of the Rifftrax gang and they don't disappoint. This movie had a few sex scenes (one of them was run twice) and that made the Rifftrax guys uncomfortable - but they did find a way to handle it that was pretty funny.The acting is so bad and the script is horrible, yet the performances are so ripe for making fun of. It is like "Manos: The Hands of Fate" bad. So awful it has become a midnight movie and pop culture phenomenon. Since watching this, I am now in on the jokes that are all over YouTube. I am sure it would be hilarious without Riffrax, but for me it was a lot of fun to watch with Mike and the Gang.SPOILER - At the end, when Johnny kills himself, they linger on the suffering of Lisa and Mark (fiance and best friend who have been doing it behind Johnny's back). Yet more egregious acting. I had to guess the writer was sending a message to someone who broke his heart! But he didn't kill himself - he sent his message this way. To the whole world. For that we are grateful!

Don't get me wrong,this movie is incredibly bad.The reason I gave it 10/10 is because it's really funny.The Room is like a cringe version of a soap opera drama.If you would play a drinking game where everybody drinks when something cringe happens you would go straight to the hospital.I really recommend seeing this movie everytime you want to watch something that have really bad reviews. It will lower your standards by 99%

reviews.review_title: THE PERFECT SCORE FOR THE PERFECT MOVIE
reviews.content: Hello ThereIf I could give this movie the one and only true perfect score 5/7 I could but since in IMDB you can rate movies out of 10 I've done the maths and the equivalent of perfect score a.k.a. 5/7 is 6.42857142857 out of 10. And since that number is a quite a little bit smaller than 6.5 I will be rating this movie 6/10.Thank you.

This is not a movie you watch for the acting, the writing, the cinematography, the screenplay, or the score.
You watch this to laugh at its writing, cinematography, th screenplay, the writing and its score.
You watch this while you're 40% drunk and would laugh more at dumbass situations rather than actual jokes.
You watch this to better appreciate The Disaster Artist, the Movie about the making of this movie, which was Oscar nominated.
And most importantly, you watch this for Tommy Wiseau. The Legend. The Genius. The Most meta-comedian in Hollywood. You would hardly find any movies that are meta-funny these days. Just go ahead and watch it, and watch the Disaster Artist next.

To sum it up briefly, it is like staring into the eyes of God and having Him say back to you, "You are my my beautiful creation." Much like the followings of The Rocky Horror Picture Show, The Room is quickly gaining a following that will go down in underground cinema history. I just recently saw this movie for the first time, and am already hooked. I cannot wait till next month when it will be shown in Hollywood again. Don't expect a good movie by any means when watching The Room, but instead, expect a movie going experience that you will never forget. Just hearing the comments veteran Room viewers yell out at the movie screen is enough to make you want to come back for more. The movie has NO CONTINUITY WHATSOEVER. It appears that the movie was never edited and that scenes are completely out of place, or in the movie for no reason. Several shots are reused scene after scene to save money on production costs. Yet, these things that are so wrong as far as regular movies go are what make The Room such a great movie. The fallacies are intentional and should be taken as such. Also, a big plus to the overall experience is the question and answer session before each screening by producer, director, writer, and lead star Tommy Wiseau. At least that is the case at all the Hollywood screenings at the Laemmle Sunset 5 on Hollywood Blvd. My advice to anyone who hasn't seen the movie yet is to see it with a friend, or a lot of friends, so that you can crack jokes with them while watching the movie. Also, you must see the movie more than once, YOU MUST. The movie is so much funnier the second time. Overall, The Room really is the best worst movie ever.
The Room absolutley fails as the romantic-drama that it intended to be. As a comedy, however, The Room is brilliant.

reviews.review_title: See how a man wasted $6 million.
reviews.content: To fully explain how bad this film is could gain me an MA if I did it at university.My god it is bad, real bad, I mean I thought Titanic 2 was the worst film I'd seen then I saw this.It's impossible to pick a worst scene but the flower shop is the closest to my favourite/worst, the dialogue feels like someone threw the script through a granulator then didn't bother to check it as the pacing is crazy, one sentence feels well out of place and this is only 20 seconds of the film!Speaking of dialogue the "Oh hai Mark" scene reportedly took Tommy 34 takes and lord knows what made him think this was the best take, surely the others couldn't have been worse.I'd recommend this film if you wanted to gain a headache or migraine and get out of work for a day, I bet if your boss found out you were pulling a sicky and you showed it to them they'd let you off.The idea that someone sat in an edit suite and thought "Yes, this is perfect" baffles me.Awful, awful, awful, awful and yet, I'd recommend it to anyone. If you thought the recent generation of films were bad, Michael Bay, JJ Abrams and so forth, then watch this because you'll appreciate them a million times more.Absolute essential viewing for anyone who's an adult.

This film is harmless so I can't give it the lowest possible rating, but my god, it's stupid. If laughing at how awful something is and having fun with that is your thing, then this is your film. Otherwise, Tommy Wiseau is atrociously bad across the board here, as a writer, actor, and director. There is not a shred of artistry in what he puts up on the screen, nor any sign of talent over the film's 99 minute runtime. I'm not sure which was greater, the number of softcore sex scenes that go on too long, the number of times the guys awkwardly throw a football around, or the number of conversations between mother and daughter where they say the same things to one another. Meanwhile, there is a tinge of misogyny in its charmless story. It's kind of depressing to me that this has such a cult following as it seems like a celebration of stupidity, but I guess unintentionally funny is just not my thing.

reviews.review_title: The worst movie ever made by either man or animal
reviews.content: No matter how low your expectations are, this movie will still manage to suck more than you thought possible. Every scene is absolutely awful. Every aspect of the movie is completely horrible, except for the pure technicals like sound and camera, which help frame how awful everything in this movie is. If they gave me a camera and specifically asked me to make the worst movie that I can, I would not be able to make something this bad. In the same time, it's entertaining, because I couldn't stop laughing at how terrible it is.

reviews.review_title: The Lonely Lady meets Ed Wood but with only 2% of the finesse.
reviews.content: As I watched The Room I thought, 'This can't be real. Seriously - this is a parody, right?' But what I've read leads me to believe that yes, the intent was to make an actual, serious movie. But it views like a perfect dead-on, deadpan parody of the worst possible movie ever. From the ludicrously inept script to the bad soft-core porn scenes to the acting that makes Edith Massey look like Agnes Moorhead - it's just ... mind-crackingly horrid. I am a fan of unintentionally bad movies (The Apple is my favorite so far) But this ... this one takes the cake. I think the line that is said the most often is "Don't worry about it!" This line is an all-purpose line that can is said in response to everything from 'I have breast cancer' to 'I am leaving you.' The second-most popular line in this movie is 'I don't want to talk about it.' This is a great device to indicate the characters like to bring things up just for the sake of dropping the topic four seconds later. I confess I had to fast-forward through much of this (like all the sex scenes) But I had to watch Johnny's breakdown. This was like watching someone imitate Christopher Walken sleepwalking. But without any of the passion. I shan't see The Room again. Not only is it aggressively inept, it's tedious. Bad piled upon bad piled upon bad with no sense of direction or purpose is hard to watch for more than ten minutes. I don't regret seeing The Room, in the same way I suppose someone wouldn't regret having been run over by a slow-moving train and living to tell the tale.

Having seen this movie a couple of times (a couple of times too many), it boggles the mind how this can not be on the bottom 100. This is, by far, the worst movie I have ever seen. This comes from someone who watched nearly every episode of MST3K, so I know my bad movies. The atmospheric scenes of San Francisco are the only redeeming thing in this cinematic pile of dung. Bitterly misogynistic and unfocused writing, bad acting, and direction without a clue are just laughable.Still, the movie is like a train wreck. you just can't turn away. the more you find out about this movie, the more Tommy Wiseau looks like a con man. I can promise you I will never attend a midnight showing of this movie (I want none of my money going to this jerk),and should I find myself at one that he is at,I would love to take the opportunity to kick him in the crotch.

reviews.review_title: Don't be tempted by the cult-status talk...
reviews.content: I like a good cult movie and so i decided to watch "The Room". A copy was hard to find to begin with but i actually managed to get a DVD from a cult videostore in the city. In hindsight, i wish i didn't find it at all.The "story" is not only slow but also simply horrible. It's a stupid story about love and life with no real message in it. The acting is horrifying, especially the main character, Johnny, played Wiseau himself. And Wiseau's laughter.. oh boy.. his laughter. Every time he went 'ah-hah-heh-heh' it made me want to vomit. Every time he spat out "Thats the idea!" with his weird french-Canadian-Croatian accent, it made me want to throw the remote at my television.And whats up with the overdubs? It's clearly visible that only Wiseau's character Johnny had been overdubbed after the film was finished. And Wiseau did a bad job at that, too. Sometimes you even hear Wiseau talking when the character Johnny isn't moving his lips, at all. Insane.The love scenes are ridiculous, after maybe 25 minutes three (really bad) love scenes came by already (and i was by now bored out of my skull already).   Throughout the movie various music tracks are played. Wiseau for reasons that are beyond me decided to use classical music AND r&b music in the same movie. Makes no sense at all.Don't be fooled by its cult status. This movie is worthless and not worth the watch. Apparently, this movie cost 6 million $ to make, IMO sure anyone else could have done a better job for 50 grand. Basically you could describe this movie as "poorly directed episode of days of our lives" -- boring, slow and not worth watching a first time, let alone a second time.Avoid at all cost.

This is the greatest bad movie I have ever seen.It's so bad, like high school movie project bad, that's it's so captivating in every way. That's entertainment for ya.I couldn't stop laughing every minute of the movie. Whether it's Tommy's delivery of his lines, the corny script, or both. The deliver of Tommy's lines are just so hilariously badly executed that it hurts to laugh."Oh hi Mark."
"You're tearing me apart, Lisa."
"Hi doggy."Just to name a few quotes.You don't have to be a serious movie critic to enjoy this movie. If you are, then obviously this movie would serve you no justice. We're not talking about Christian Bale level of acting here. Tommy acts like doesn't care about the critics. His style of acting, or let alone his delivery, just makes the movie worth watching to laugh at.

Yes, I was led to this movie by the Nostalgia Critic, without whom I probably never would have bothered to see this movie. I'm surprised I even decided to watch this monstrosity of movie because just watching the few clips the Critic used in his review was almost unbearable. BUT, I digress---this movie did get a laugh out of me, even if it obviously wasn't intended.Like everyone else has already mentioned, the acting was horrendous. I couldn't believe what I was watching...literally couldn't believe because the acting was not believable at any part of the movie. I felt no connection to any of the characters or to the story. I didn't feel bad, like I should have, when Johnny took his life. It wasn't just because there would be no more silly lines coming out of his mouth, but because there was no in-depth connection with him that I usually feel for a character when they die. Mufasa's death was more traumatizing than this.And of course, everyone talks about the sex scenes in "The Room". Seriously the most awkward sex I've ever seen in any movie...usually it's smooth and passionate and most of all, again, believable. Oh, and I loved seeing Tommy Wiseau's backside...he should just go around naked from now on because I'm sure people want to see that! Not. Why was this even called "The Room"? Was it because Johnny and Lisa had awkward sex in a room? Heck, it should have been called "The Spiral Staircase", if that's what they were getting at! The title is even misleading! It sounds like a horror film, like bad things happen in a specific room and you just don't go in there. But no. There's sex and death in one room. Wow.I have to say my favorite line in this movie was when Johnny was "raving" about how he didn't hit Lisa. I laughed so hard, I cried, and watched that scene a couple more times. The guy didn't even look mad when he threw the water bottle! (In fact, did Tommy have ANY expression on his face through the duration of the movie?) And then the quick, nonchalant "Oh hey, Mark" felt misplaced and awkward after the "rant". As if he knew Mark was there and planned to walk out "griping" about Lisa, then pretend he didn't know Mark was there.Well, if anything, this movie made me laugh. So many things made me uncomfortable because of how they were presented to the audience; I couldn't sit back and enjoy the movie at all. There was nothing to enjoy! So I thank the Nostalgia Critic for directing me to this film so I could see for myself how hilariously terrible it is. From now on, I think I'll let him remember it so I don't have to.

reviews.review_title: Will Restore Your Faith in Good Filmmaking
reviews.content: Many of the public lack a proper appreciation for the artistry that goes into films. They take 'the movies' for granted: just another part of popular culture. 'The Room' can restore that appreciation, not from any virtues which it possesses, but from the lack thereof. In short, The Room is an object lesson in what results from a production lacking artistry. This includes the performances, the script, the photography, the editing, the soundtrack....All these elements lack artistry in this film, and the results are so sadistic, that one will never lack an appreciation for good filmmaking ever again after seeing this movie. Some have described it as a traffic accident. I don't think this really does it justice. You might recall an accident in upstate NY a few years back. It involved an intoxicated mother carrying 5 or 6 children that collided head on with a vehicle with a father and his son riding in it, in which everyone but one child in the mother's car was killed. You catch my drift....After watching The Room, I don't think anyone could ever again be under the impression that good films just happen, or that making films is easy, or that little effort is required. 'The Room' will forever remain a testament to what the art of film sans 'art' is: and for that we owe the producers a debt of gratitude.

Greetings from Lithuania.I won't going to tell anything new that wasn't said about "The Room" (2003) a cult movie, "Citizen Kane" of awful movies. The only reason i picked it up is because of "The Disaster Artist" (2017) - an upcoming movie about creation of this "masterpiece"."The Room" is hilariously bad - this is what happens when lead "artist" beyond the wheel without any talent tries to create something out of league. If you don't know how - maybe sometimes its better not to do instead of doing and then becoming a joke target for centuries. I do admire that Tommy Wiseau at least tried to so something he was passioned about nevertheless. Overall, there isn't much to say about this movie actually. It is hilariously bad picture, where nothing works, and its done so bad that i kinda watched scene after scene with my eyes wide open in disbelief that it can't be worse that this. This picture is funny in how it is bad, and that is the best one can say about this trashy little picture.

Once again, this is one of those times when I wish I could give a movie a 0 or, even better, a negative number. But I guess I'll have to settle for a 1.People are honestly comparing this to other cult movie classics? How dare they? Even comparing it to Plan 9 From Outer Space isn't fair to Ed Wood. At least there were good parts and laughable parts in Plan 9. There's absolutely nothing redeeming about this movie and certainly no humor in it whatsoever. It's not a black comedy.
