The sad thing is that Tommy Wiseau put so much passion into this project that I would honestly recommend watching this movie over any exchangeable contemporary superhero sequel flooding the world's cinemas. The Room is one of those movies you should have watched once in your lifetime for all the reasons stated above. I'm sure I will watch it again with a bunch of friends after having just discovered this film on my own this week.

Finally got around to this and WHEW! It did not disappoint! The Room is ridiculously bad. It makes no sense, it's over and under acted, it's awful.But I laughed SO MUCH! This is a train wreck I can't look away from yet I have so much fun with how awful it is. It truly may be the greatest bad movie ever made. Logically, this fails hard but I just can't give a poor rating to something I got so much joy out of. I will be laughing about, quoting and having fun with this for a while.

reviews.review_title: Unintentionally or intentionally funny and weird drama.
reviews.content:
Everyone makes fun of this movie, some hate it, some love it. Some think it's misunderstood gem, some think it's one of the worst movies of all time. To be fair I do like the premise of this movie, but everything goes so weird, I don't even call it bad, it's just bizzare. Just to name a few interesting unexplained things: Spoon art, weird dialogues, recycled sex scenes, weird acting, the suspicious relationship between Denny and Johnny/Lisa and many many more things.
I do believe this movie is worth watching, it does have some unpredicatable things and for most part it's a very funny and unique film. You should atleast respect the creator as he alone wrote/directed/procuced/starred in this movie at the same time and all was made from his own money, no support. That's a lot of effort and love put into this film.

Where do you even begin with this film? It's a plane crashing into a fireworks factory manned by chimpanzees.If you've never seen this; please do. Grab your cinephile buddies, some spoons and some hard liquor because you're in for an experience like no other (except maybe Troll 2 or Birdemic)As far as actual film-making actually goes this is an abomination. However as an entertainment spectacle I've never enjoyed a film more. Both 1 out of 10 and 10 out of 10. This film is impossible to black and white rate. As a side note I recommend The Disaster Artist a book Greg Sestero wrote on the making of the film; both informative and tragically hilarious.

In the SBIG category a movie that is possibly the #1 So Bad It's Good, this is a movie that spawned a wonderful flick and cult status. The Room is written by, directed by, produced by and stars Tommy Wiseau, a millionaire of foreign extraction, so foreign that it makes for problems with understanding his diction. Okay, that's a lie, it's his acting that makes for problems understanding. Probably the best SBIG element is his acting, but the writing is a very close second. As unintentionally funny as this flick is I can only give it a grudging good review because of the interminable sex scenes that make me want to claw at my eyes. Just saying.Johnny is such a good guy. Everybody just looooooooves him. Even the teenage boy from the sixth floor wants to jump his bones. I mean, he does, he just jumps right in the middle of Johnny and his fiancé as they romp fully clothed on their bed! And when he does the couple just laugh as if that's the cutest dang thing. Except of course Johnny sternly tells the kid to get lost on accounta there's sweet loving afoot. The whole movie is replete with scenes that never in a million years would ever happen twixt people, which is a kind of joy.

reviews.review_title: A movie so bad that my Netflix DVD copy skipped a few times into the film so i returned it without warning...
reviews.content: The upcoming release of The Disaster Artist, about the making of this terrible movie, has increased popularity of this little known yet increasingly popular cult movie that failed big time at the box office when it opened in 2003 yet became The Rocky Horror Picture Show for the millenial generation and beyond. It has been so popular that many Youtubers have created what ifs for popular hit movies based on the room.

reviews.review_title: This movie is SO bad....it's funny!
reviews.content: Okay to start off with yes I did give this movie a 9, but those who have seen the review of this done by the Nostalgia Critic would understand why I rated it so high.To start off with I had NEVER heard of this film up until I saw the review by the NC. To say the least I was both shocked and laughing hard as the review progressed. After a while you start to realize that this film is more of a guilty pleasure than being down right horrible. Yes the acting is horrific and the storyline is quite cliché. On the other hand you have to give Tommy Wiseau SOME credit for trying to make a dollar. If there's anything I've learned from this movie it would be these:1) Have an affair with your future husband in public 2) Throw around a football with tuxes on 3) Take shockingly bad news rather decently 4) Make cat noises when fighting with your best friend, AND! 5) Always ask if someone is dead when they obviously are.Overall there's not much else to say, like the NC said it's really worth checking out granted we don't get yelled at by those copyright nazi's over at Wiseau Films. Nonetheless it's worth picking up at the video store if you have nothing else to do that night.Hope this was helpful!

reviews.review_title: Between the intermittent cataracts of Spoon River . . .
reviews.content: . . . THE ROOM unfolded at my local Bijou as the story of a Boy and his Gun, climaxing as the former exercises his Second Amendments Rights through his timely use of the latter. "Johnny's" steel-jacketed muse is named "Lisa," and every time Lisa entered THE ROOM the hordes of misogynistic pigs filling my theater showered thousands of mostly plastic spoons up in the air and down on the rows of swine grunting and squealing in front of them, while shouting original slogans such as "F. Lisa!" (This reminded me of all those 2016 "Lock her up!" rallies.) "Johnny," who also happens to be the producer, writer, and director of THE ROOM in addition to taking a stab at being its main character, includes a gratuitous distant slow pan along San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge every five minutes or so. Each of these tedious intervals elicited drunken screams of "Jump! Jump!! Jump!!!" from my audience (even though none of this flick's characters were even visible in this apparent "stock footage" shot from five miles away). About every 10 minutes THE ROOM featured lit "romantic" candles, something aped again by all the Brainiac Guys at my showing. So when Johnny's ex-best-friend "Mark" seems about to revive him from having blown his brains out because Mark did Lisa many times behind his back, our Big Screen started flaring up from all the flammable spoons and poorly extinguished candles, leaving only fire fighters to view the results of Mark's efforts. So it goes.

reviews.review_title: A Shockingly Bad Yet Surprisingly Entertaining and Ironically Hilarious Piece of Cinema.
reviews.content: The Room... directed by Tommy Wiseau... I don't need to say anything else about this movie. It basically speaks for itself. It's the most notorious indie-drama of the 2000s and it's production resulted in co-star Greg Sestero to write the novel 'The Disaster Artist', chronicling the making of 'The Citizen Kane of Bad Movies'. And now The Disaster Artist is getting its own movie; directed by James Franco, who will also play Tommy Wiseau in the film; additionally, Dave Franco will play Greg Sestero. And The Room actually deserves a movie based around its legacy, because this film has a cult following like no other and a warped-beyond-comprehension fandom that embraces the film's unintentional campiness. Basically, it's an ironic masterpiece that's so bad it's amazing!The movie has dialogue that makes even the worst screen writing seem like the works of Robert Towne and Orson Welles; it's especially funny here because Wiseau actually cites Welles as a massive inspiration on his work. And... Tommy Wiseau has set such an admirably unique low-bar for indie-cinema that its effects on the indie film industry inspired lesser filmmakers to pick up their wits when making their passion projects. If Reservoir Dogs set the bar for quality and smart indie-cinema, then The Room set it for belief- suspending campiness full of WTF moments and nonsensical subplots that would inspire the likes of Birdemic, A Talking Cat and Cool Cat Saves The Kids. And The Room started this absurdity.The Room; it's like an alien trying to figure out how character drama works without realising anything about natural human behaviour or character. And that alien would be a very 'special' one.

Seriously, this movie is very bad. But it's a crapload of funny. We are laughing at how horrible the movie is. The acting is laughably bad too. Hey Tommy we're laughing with you AND at you! BWAHHAH!For example, in the rooftop scene, Johnny says, 'O hai Mark.' Pretty hilarious and unexpected mood swinger. Johnny may say some weird stuff and I don't get why. But Johnny's breakdown is wimpy and weak. I really wish I heard about the movie before though. So bad in completing its purpose, but it was so bad it's hilarious! And I've seen posts calling this movie a masterpiece. Really. I'll assume that's sarcasm. What a story Tommy Wiseau.

reviews.review_title: Stands Outside of Time, Space and Good Taste
reviews.content: The Room is a film directed, written, produced, starring and likely catered by fame-seeker and wannabe cultural icon Tommy Wiseau. Johnny (Wiseau) our Dramamine swilling protagonist is a seemingly perfect human being who lives in San Francisco with his fiancée Lisa (Danielle). He exercises regularly running and playing catch with neighborhood urchin Denny (Haldiman). He also goes to his job to do business stuff. One day, Lisa wakes up realizing she no longer loves Johnny and seduces his best friend Mark (Sestero). All of the couple's mutual friends think Lisa's actions are despicable while Lisa's mother (Minnott) believes Johnny is the key to Lisa's financial security and she shouldn't call off the wedding. That is about as much plot as you can gleam out of this impossibly contrived film which aims for the melodrama of Dallas (1978-1991) but ends up feeling like a two act play written by second graders.The Room is considered one of the worst movies ever made which, after a very brief first life in theaters, has become a midnight screening staple and so- bad-it's-good classic to eye-rolling hipsters and giddy schlock fans. Boasting inept direction, screen writing, cinematography, lighting, acting, special-effects, editing, et al., The Room is essentially a master course of what NOT to do when it comes to film-making. Yet despite the film's almost willful ignorance to straightforward storytelling, the film has an appeal that defies logic. Like watching the hypnotic gaze of an esurient asp, The Room puts you in a trance and forces you to sit through the entire f***ing thing; from it's softcore porn bedroom scenes to it's woman hating living room scenes.I had the pleasure of sitting through this movie among the right crowd and found myself laughing often and hard. The film's artless bubbling; every moment of amateurishness was done in just about the worst way possible allowing the audience to become flabbergasted by it all. Wiseau has said that his biggest influences for The Room were films like Rebel Without a Cause (1955), and the collective works of Elizabeth Taylor, Tennessee Williams and Alfred Hitchcock. In reality the film is more an ugly-looking amalgam of everything an Eastern European immigrant would assume appeals to an American audience including extended moments of alley way football.One would need to watch this affront to celluloid countless times before they can truly discover how a movie like this could be so popular among certain crowds. Perhaps one place to start looking would be Wiseau's absolutely appalling performance as Johnny. Unlike the other "actors" that flood the screen, Wiseau doesn't just approach the script with amateurish drudgery. His idiosyncratic delivery, clumsy blocking and confusing chatter reaches new heights in gleeful, over-the-top nuttiness. It feels as if Wiseau was sent from another planet to make a movie as a test to see if they can assimilate. If in the years to come it's discovered there's been a They Live (1988) meets The X-Files (1993-present) season 9 type conspiracy, one would only need to see The Room to discover where it all started.The Room stands outside of time and space and certainly outside of the history of cinema. It's a movie that defies logic; a movie that proves quite entertaining if given the right circumstances but if slightly less overwrought would have been completely forgotten. Wiseau has appeared at many viewings of the film and bolsters his inflated ego as a purposeful disaster artist who revels in sardonic satire. I personally don't believe him for a minute. The frantic, neurotic emotional core of The Room is arguably the only thing about the film that felt genuine. That and two characters' uncomfortable obsession with chocolate. Seriously guys, get a room.

reviews.review_title: So bad it's good? Not really, it's just bad.
reviews.content: I totally get watching a movie with a knowing smile and one's tongue firmly in cheek as you watch this train wreck of a film get absolutely everything wrong. I understand why it has a cult following: it is almost a masterclass in film making ineptitude. But surely giving this film a rating of 10 subverts that notoriety? Whatever.Simply put, this is a big, pile of steaming rubbish. Technically it is no better (and indeed, in many ways worse) than a cheap day time soap opera. There seems to be a lack of basic blocking, framing and focus. The acting is universally atrocious with the 'actors' blurting out lines with the same verve as first time porn performers. The script is incoherent with a multitude of incomplete story arcs, google translate dialogue and utterly insane narrative. You could forgive any of these issues if this were made and conceived by 7 year olds but the fact that this is made by actual, real grown ups makes one question our progression as a species.I read somewhere that this cost 6 million dollars to make. I would love to see the budget breakdown because just about any film student could make this with some amateur actors and an iphone and it would be better. So yeah, I get it: it is really, really bad. Maybe one of worst movies to ever get a release. But it's cult status does not make it a 10/10 movie.

reviews.review_title: A Rocket RollerCoaster set for an explosion!
reviews.content: Tommy Wiseau's "The Room" is a truely wonderful timeless film with a large cast in miscellaneous locations. I have seen this movie three times and each time I get something new out of it. With a sharp blend of Arnold Schwarzennegger, Van Damn, and Dr. Frankenstein's monster   Tommy's performance is brilliant, hilarious, powerful, and even moving at some points. The screenplay & dialogue are even better pushing the limits of seventh grade drama. Armed with a blind cinematography and tri-pod supported by a one legged dwarf the film shows real life situations in a raw and entertaining manner. All the characters are loveable and enjoyable to watch, especially Denny a lifelike teenage puppet with the sensitive heart of gold. The character "arch" goes all over the place like a rocket rollercoaster too confused to stay on the track but entertaining none the less. I loved this movie, it may sound like I am being cynical but really I am not! This is tommy's first movie and by golly it is fun (just as long as you don't take it seriously). I think that this film will definitely find an audience and a large cult following. I recommend this quirky "dark comedy" drama sitcom play movie to anyone who loves to laugh and enjoys a good time. his movie gives amateur filmmakers hope for the future. Thanks Tommy, you taught us to laugh and love again. 9 3/8 stars!

reviews.review_title: "I don't want to talk about it"
reviews.content:
Most people just do not understand Tommy Wiseau. Literally. Because of his accent. This movie is unlike anything that has come before or will come after; it is a fact you should keep in mind when watching it. And once you've seen it, it is a memorable event you won't forget.
Have you ever seen a movie that is such a masterfully executed work of art it transcends the need for any story, gripping or otherwise? Such movies, however rare, can be found.
Some directors safely follow the proven formula of what makes a great movie; others experiment and take bold approaches with their film-making for equally great results. These are two different ways to produce quality movies.
Tommy Wiseau bet everything he had on this movie; the result is something that can't really be defined within the constraints of a star rating system; it matters not whether you give it one or ten stars and so I literally flipped a coin for this review in the spirit of Tommy's bet on his vision.I will say this: when I first heard about The Room I was told not to watch it alone, but organize my first viewing with a group of like-minded friends and copious amounts of the finest beverage available. And I am glad I waited years for this to happen, as The Room is an experience you have to share. It is then and only then you will appreciate it in its fullest for the ode to love, sensuality, friendship and football throwing it is.

reviews.review_title: A Telling of the Modern American Women
reviews.content: In all honesty I actually enjoyed this movie and did not think it was bad like everyone else does. It is sickening how shallow, uncaring, and horrible people are these days that they just laugh at this and find it humorous. The movie both exposes what the typical Modern American/Western Women has become and at the same time it exposes how horrible, heartless, and ill-minded the people are that watch this and laugh about it. Being cheated on by the love of your life with someone you thought was your friend is not a funny thing to go through in life and I only hope that the people who laugh at this may one day have to endure the same thing themselves. Maybe then they will understand, however I doubt they will even care or even genuinely love the person they are with and probably cheat on them all the time. If you are reading this "Tommy Wiseau" please know that at least 1 person genuinely enjoyed your film and found it emotionally moving. It is not you who failed at making a good movie, it is like your movie shows with modern women failing to be good people that modern Americans fail to be good people.

reviews.review_title: To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Tommy Wiseau's The Room.
reviews.content:
The humour is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of theoretical physics most of the jokes will go over a typical viewer's head. There's also Johnny's nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his characterisation- his personal philosophy draws heavily from Narodnaya Volya literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these jokes, to realise that they're not just funny- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike The Room ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the humour in Johnny's existential catchphrase "I did not hit her! It's not true! It's bullshit, I did not hit her! I did not!... Oh, hai Mark!" which itself is a cryptic reference to Turgenev's Russian epic Fathers and Sons. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Tommy Wiseau's genius wit unfolds itself on their television screens. What fools.. how I pity them. 
And yes, by the way, I DO have a "Oh hi, doggie" scene tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies eyes only- and even then they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand. Nothing personnal kid.

reviews.review_title: An infamously atrocious cinematic blend with bad acting, bad writing, and overall bad execution spirals into an unusual appetite of "so bad it's good"
reviews.content: More often than not, when Hollywood falls into the misfortune of slapping audiences with a bottom-of-the-barrel cinematic atrocity, the final fate is it spirals into obscurity with virtually everyone forgetting about its existence within a matter of a year (maybe less). Then there is rare films such as 'The Room' that succeed at achieving the strange feat of soaking the audiences with laughter for how horrendous it is in quality. That is where Polish-born director Tommy Wiseau (or wherever on Earth he was born, who knows?) and his friend Greg Sestero come in. After a longtime struggle to sell their script to major studios, it was up to this duo to come up with their independent black comedy. The results are something initially unsurprising: a disastrous, slipshod, horribly acted slugfest that spent the following ten years growing an unusual cult status from audiences who relish in laughing at the final product for how wildly inept it is. In short, it is a rare cinematic pain- inducer that everyone is willing to withstand. So the story here follows Johnny (played by Tommy Wiseau), a San Francisco banker who is on his way to marrying his long-time girlfriend Lisa (played by Juliette Danielle). What the poor sap doesn't know however, is that Lisa has grown bored of him and decides she is not in love with him and has unexpectedly fell in love with his best friend Mark (played by Greg Sestero). Although Mark is initially reluctant, not wanting to soil his friendship with Johnny), Lisa is too persitent and pulls him into a romance that soon sends everyone's lives in a downward spiral.This film completes the handbook of how not to make a cinematic picture: horrendous acting, despicable excuse of a script, production values that would fit best for a middle school play, and dialogue that is just flat out bad to the core. If you wondering about the story, well, that's pretty much of an eye-roller as well. But Tommy Wiseau's mysterious distortion of artistic value evokes the mystery of how one can make such an atrocity and somehow provide a oddly fresh source of laughter. Wiseau, spending the entirety phoning in a mawkish performance and delivering his lines with total lack of authenticity, puts on the show with his goofy chemistry with Juliette Danielle. But once Lisa's plan to disavow her engagement with Johnny takes action, that is when the unintentional hilarity ensues. Each scene taking a place on the rooftop with the San Francisco, tacked in sloppy green-screen effects, has moments of "so bad, it's good moments" spectacle. Nearly every other scene, however, slips into the cracks of "so inept, it's just bad". That is not even including Wiseau's braindead way to filming and editing each scene, especially in the overlong sex scenes in which we witness repeated footage of Wiseau's nude back. Secondly, how often do you go to a friend's house and find pictures of silverware in the living room? Now that is just silly. Above all, the events that transpire are too short of substance in terms of execution the point where even the unintentional hilarity factor has difficult to dig up.The Room may indeed fit perfectly in the category one of the worst movies in cinematic history, but in its own special way. Regardless, the level of ridiculousness still falls too shallow to uphold a proper "good because it's bad" spectacle. It is more of just plain bad and not enough of funny bad, which is simply disappointing to say the least.

What the hell did I just watch?! Everything about this movie makes no sense. From the plotting, to the characters, to the dialogue, absolutely nothing coalesces or has any logic to it. Simply put it's a collection of scenes which move the plot to its inexorable conclusion. No attempt is made whatsoever to develop any character. It's all exposition. The entire movie is exposition. Yet, the movie still has this weird charm that makes it funny even if you might struggle through the clunky dialogue. There's also a few sex scenes which are laughably bad and go on a little too long. Despite the entire movie being "wrong", it is entertaining in a sense. This is the kind of movie you watch late at night with your friends, drink and laugh about how bad it is. Recommended if you like "so bad it's good" movies (even if it doesn't quite live up to the "good" part).

reviews.review_title: You Call That A Film? (contains what for other movies would be spoilers)
reviews.content: The next time I have an earth shattering bowel movement that leaves my anus torn and bleeding I'm going to be grateful that's all that is happening to me and that I am not in fact watching 'The Room' again... and when one day I am lying withered and ill upon my death bed, dying a slow death from either cancer or heart disease I'm going to rejoice in the fact that at least I am not suffering through 'The Room' again... Now, I have been hearing tales about this film for some years and it seems to be generally received by those who witness it as one of if not the worst made film of this millennium. That's got to be worth it hasn't it? Well, yes and no... The plot of 'The Room' is fairly simple - man loves woman, woman cheats on man, man kills himself... however the real problem is that it took the film about 50 minutes to actually make it clear that this was going to be the plot and the stunningly vague and indifferent way the story was presented amidst such side plots as the cheating whores mother having cancer or one of the minor recurring characters being attacked on a rooftop by a gun wielding drug dealer. The dealer was chased off and nothing was mentioned of it or his drug problems again, or in fact preceding this randomly inserted scene, and as to the whole cancer sub-plot, well, her mother mentioned it once and was told by her daughter not to worry and then it was dropped never to be seen again. I'm serious. It appears that Tommy Wiseau (who wrote, directed, produced and starred) doesn't have even the first idea of character development or in fact how to make a film, and by all accounts this cost $6million to make... So what else could be wrong then? How about four of the most painfully gratuitous and unrealistic intercourse scenes in the history of film within the first forty minutes? Presumably this was meant to titillate the audience or maybe to drum up some interest in the slowly moving and badly mumbled story but as a tactic it failed to do so spectacularly.Without wishing to sound too disrespectful if you look at the movies poster then you can see the face of Tommy Wiseau Negative and yet the first sex scene not only involves him as the leading male but also a great shot of his scrotum. Yup. I have seen that mans balls and it wasn't pretty. How on earth was that meant to sell the film? An interesting thing to note with it is that many of the actors (my apologies to any real actors out there) were not the initial ones cast as during the production many just, erm, left and so had to be replaced by understudies (or members of the crew) including the female lead... and boy does it show! There's a brilliant scene in the film where the four men are wearing tuxedos, one of them shocks the others by having shaved off his excuse for a beard and then they go outside and play catch. It may not sound brilliant, but when you take into account that there is no explanation for the fancy clothes, no explanation for the shaving and no plot based purpose for playing catch it suddenly becomes marvellous and a perfect example of how this movie was structured. Continually throughout there are pointless bits of dialogue and whole scenes that serve no purpose, they don't add to the plot or characterisation, they aren't even well shot! It pays to keep an eye out for some of the poorest points such as the camera going out of focus mid scene, badly synced dubbing (sometimes without anyones lips moving) and my favourite of cinematic tricks - not actually fitting everyone on screen at once when you were clearly trying to. There is no real sense of consistency or continuity here and that's probably why it's so bad... That and of course Tommy Wiseau who can hardly speak intelligible English. If you want to subject yourself to something as bad as bad can be then you might want to try this film, and I'd suggest a drinking game for it too - simply have a shot anyone (particularly Wiseau) says "Oh, hi..." or anytime someone says "don't worry", you'll be too drunk to care about the film within thirty minutes or less and will be drinking to most of the films dialogue too. Honestly, those are the two most repeated phrases in the film to the point where you'll end up cheering every time you hear someone utter them... it's a strange experience and quite frankly that's how I'd best describe it, as an experience. You won't be able to call it entertainment and you certainly can't call it art, but if you watch it then you do get the strange feeling that your brain is being horribly abused and might melt out of your head due to the inconsistencies and of course the repeated shots of Wiseau's face. In an ideal world this movie would be banned under the Genoeva Convention but as well know this world is far from perfect so you can just buy it on DVD, although I strongly urge you to steal it instead. Morally no-one will be able to fault you for not paying. Believe me when I say I could go on about all the ways this failed but would rather you just saw it for yourself, my words cannot do justice to it by a long way...

This movie was an absolute mess... but why did I watch it 3 times? It's a film that will live in infamy forever. I cannot stop quoting this movie. It is truly a movie from another planet. Digging deeper to find out who Tommy Wiseau is only makes this movie better. I highly recommend this movie to any movie buff. It needs to be seen.... oh hi Mark

3/15/18. I had to watch this after I saw The Disaster Artist. This is like a bad soap opera that has gone completely off the wall. It's so cheesy because the acting was so bad although the story of infidelity as portrayed here is extremely sad. Though Sestero may have wrote the book, The Disaster Artist, his acting here is no better than anyone else's, or pretty bad.

At first glance, this is just one of the worst films I've seen but then on thinking further there are a lot of small and intricate reasons that makes it even worse. From all the backstory I've heard till now, I can only think that Tommy Wiseau isn't mentally stable. I can easily see that why The Disaster Artist could be great. Usually, in such bad films, they include sex scenes for attracting viewers and that works in the case of most B movies. A significant achievement of The Room must be the multiple sex scenes that aren't remotely arousing even with enough nudity. I hope in future I will get a chance of watching this film in one of those midnight screenings where the viewers throw spoons to the screen, otherwise never revisiting this abomination.

reviews.review_title: The Room: What more to say...
reviews.content: The Room has such a reputation of being one of the worst movies ever made by the infamous Tommy Wiseau. However I really disagree. I've seen so many bad movies (The Stuff, Birdemic 1 & 2) that makes me want to pull my own hair out but there's something about this movie that makes you learn things, especially about filmmaking. It teaches you the values of what to avoid and how NOT to go down Wiseau's route. The cinematography and lighting is pretty good but unfortunately my greatest criticism is Wiseau's input on the overall film i.e. directing, writing and even starring as the legendary Johnny. There are so many things about 'The Room' that simply doesn't make sense (lines of dialogue and even the plot). Mark's bizarre decisions in life, Lisa's motive to ruin people's lives and even choices of what to actually say like "Did you get the promotion" "Nah" "You didn't get it did you?".The summarise it up. I would recommend 'The Room' to everyone simply because no one has ever seen anything like this before for it's 'originality'. It's not the worst film ever made, but I bet once you witness the magic, you'll never want to witness it ever again.

As i write this, I weep for the future of humanity. The Room is an existential masterpiece, an exemplar of what not to do in a way that will enliven any film discussion group towards an awareness that life is mockery and life, arm in arm with its Vaudeville exotic dance partner, death, should be treated as such. Thank you dear Tom, for recalibrating the great and universal yardstick of aesthetics before which we all lay prostrate in humble absent mindedness and a delicious, if abject, shrug of the shoulder. The Room has taken possession of my soul, I can speak no further.

reviews.review_title: Cult film for people who have no idea of actual cult films
reviews.content: Why this gets the attention it does is a mystery. I can only put it down to vapid hipster culture. No different to teeny boppers rushing from one boy band to another. Dumb insects attracted to flashing lights. One hipster told another hipster who then told two. Then four etc. Suddenly a "cult classic". If you want weird and bizarre, try _The Bold and the Beautiful_ when they had their demonic possession episode series which is infinitely more entertaining than this. Hipsters are a social cancer. This is evidence.

reviews.review_title: The Best "So Bad It's Good" Movie EVER
reviews.content: This (obviously) is the worst film in the history of anything, but it is worth seeing because of one man. Tommy Wiseau. His acting is like an alien came down from space and saw a 12 year old's short film and thought it was the best acting he'd ever seen, so he made Tommy Wiseau with the acting skills of that 12 year old. It's so utterly bad that it makes it wonderful to watch. I recomend you see it with a couple of friends so you can have a good laugh together.

This Movie has perhaps the greatest director to have ever written a movie. I am not biased at all. (Spoiler Alert) The Room is about a banker whose wife is cheating with his best friend. Of all the movies from 2003, The Room should be on the top of your watch list. Tommy Wiseau did a terrific job in this movie, and was by far the greatest actor in this movie. Again, I'm not biased whatsoever. The Room is also a good family movie, with no inappropriate scenes. Goodbye, and thanks for all the fish.P.S. Also watch Superbabies 2 P.P.S Also watch Cool Cat saves the kidsYou won't be disappointed

From a critics perspective it would be a complete failure as a movie, a 0/10. but for my rating wich is based on how much I enjoyed it i would give it a 5/10. just because the movie is terrible doesn't mean you cant enjoy it. there is a point on wich the movie is so bad you dont mind the mistakes and just laugh.5/10: jokingly bad

reviews.review_title: CHEER! - (1 star out of 10) - Rare Case of Cheering A Bomb
reviews.content: The stage curtains open ...Someone called this a "masterpiece" in their review. No. Definitely NOT a masterpiece. Cult favorite? Okay, that I would buy.When Tommy Wiseau and Greg Sestero couldn't make it big in movies, they decided to make their own. What Wiseau set out to do was create a masterpiece. What he gave to the world is the worst movie to ever be shown on the silver screen. Yeah ... it was really THAT bad. There is no logical flow, terrible acting (if you can even call it that), contradictions in nearly every scene, unanswered questions, and god awful dialogue - this film was so embarrassingly horrible, that you can't help but laugh at its outrageousness. The more dramatic it tried to be, the harder I laughed.This movie is a paradox, a rarity in terms. You could never feel justified in recommending it to anyone, and yet you can't wait to share it with your friends because it is SO terrible, that you want them to see it - if only for the reason that you can say to them, "See what I mean?!?" - LOLIt is easy to see why this film has risen to cult status. And why the rather GOOD movie, "The Disaster Artist", was created in its honor. I hated this movie so much, that I actually loved it. Then why have I rated it only 1 star out of 10? Because it still sucks - Thank you to everyone who have "indirectly supported" this review - (fade out to the sound of fire engine sirens blaring ominously in the background....)

Let's get the spoiler out of the way: Nothing happens... or at least nothing that makes any sense, that contributes to any sense of a narrative, human interaction or intrigue.With that said let's address the gaping maw of the beast that is The Room directly, though beware, its breath is as bad as the corpse our 'dashing lead' resembles.Now, I saw the rifftrax version of this movie, that is to say that even some fairly horrendous flaws I could forgive for the sheer enjoyment Kevin, Michael and Bill provide but it proved to be like sprinkling a decaying kangaroo with sugar. The acting is atrocious from all corners, the directing and script seem to be scenes from rejected movies sewn together only where Doctor Frankenstein produced something intelligent and provocative at least this resembles a bolt-necked, cat headed monstrosity with a left leg where its right arm should be.Too many death analogies? Sure, but what do you expect after 100 painful minutes staring at Tommy Wiseau? The jerky, creepy, inhuman, zombie like dialogue is the first example I've ever seen of human speech plumbing the depths of the uncanny valley. A kid who likes to watch his father figure have sex, (who incidentally has a love interest of his own we never see and a drug problem that amounts to half a scene of padding) a woman with no motivation in life other than to be thoroughly unpleasant in the national leagues, the ridiculous and inexplicable mother with cancer that doesn't seem to be slowing her down much... I could go on. There is no plot to this movie, there is no justification to anything Now we move on to the scenes that give this movie an r Rating, the sex scenes, the saviour of many a bad movie's sales. If you're looking for nudity cloaked by a story you're better off watching that one with the Swedish plumber with the horrendous moustache... or even pride and prejudice. This movie fails on both sex appeal and story. The doughy, fortysomething flesh dragging lethargically over the bed is about as sexy as filling two forty pound bags with meat and slapping them together. I honestly felt a little sick and decided to run a game leaving only the audio track in the background about 10 minutes in.That leaves us with one one question - is it so bad it's good? No. Just no. As previously mentioned this is right there in the uncanny, unfunny, unpleasant trough of any graph of likability you care to draw up. The dialogue is so jarring and stupid you just end up feeling numb and the acting is sub-children's nativity and that's not hyperbole. This movie was so bad RiffTrax actually waived their 'no R rated movies' policy just to cover this train wreck and that should give you an idea of how awful this is.Sorry, Mike and the bots, not even you guys could save this experience from being painful, nauseating and ugly in every sense of the word. How it got a 4/10 I have no idea.

reviews.review_title: Enjoyably Horrible! All deserving the hype
reviews.content: For moviephiles, we get attached to genres and subplots. The room has none of that. As a matter of fact, The Room is so random and unintelligible, that is becomes a cold reboot of everything we've come to know about movies.Does it break the 4th wall? Kinda...... But not intentionally which makes it everything people talk about. It's re-watchable too. And now that The Disaster Artist is out, it will give you a different take on how you may have thought it was created.No, it's not genius, and far from it. The Room is pure hope, and drive. It's a celebration in lack of talent and direction. It showcases a sense of strange mainstreaming that everyone should at least take note of. Real life is unscripted and random. It can be fun, and the Room is fun!! Tommy Wiseau might be the most authentic protagonist to the abnormality in us all. That's not a bad thing, and we shouldn't be ashamed. We should celebrate our own shortcomings because that's what life is.The Room is so wonderfully awful (as has been said a thousand time before). But it gives us all a reason to spotlight certain traits that make us all special. Enjoy every day, and if it's awful, find a reason to laugh. We only make this journey once, so have fun with it! No spoilers needed.

reviews.review_title: Silly, Low Budget, and it Knows
reviews.content: You probably watched this after that Vox video as I did.The Room is a fun, low-budget film that doesn't hesitate to cover its mistakes. The movie tries to be serious but ends up as a comedy. It's a fun movie to watch with friends and is quite quotable.1/5. Though I did have fun with this movie, I do have to be honest.

A terrible movie, only made painfully funny given the horrid script and acting.There are moments in this movie which defy explanation. Give the oddity of Wiseau, you have to wonder if you a watching some strange insight into the mind of this man, or if he might just be plain f'd. The love scenes are some of the most difficult viewing ever put to DVD. And the rampage of Johnny is just so staged. Football seems to be everywhere for no reason. Lisa's mother... Jesus. "You are tearing me apart Lisa!" "I did not hit her... arg, I did nahit." "and I'm dying..."Watch it if you're into the worst of the worst in life. F

Everyone who thinks this movie is bad should "Leave their stupid comments in their pockets!"You'll be watching it with confusion but also feel very entertainted, words cannot express how good and how bad this movie is at the same time.We didn't deserve you Tommy, we didn't deserve you...

reviews.review_title: Plan 9 is Oscar worthy compared to this nonsense
reviews.content: I read through about 20 of the 84 reviews for this movie and I started wondering if everyone had seen the same movie as me. I saw reviews that raved about the movie but gave it a 1 out of 10. I just finished watching it on Cartoon Network of all places. The acting was horrible. None of the actors in this film were believable. The story line was complete drivel. It barely held my interest. I've had more fun watching grass grow.At the end of the movie, just before "Johnny" shoots himself over his fiancé's betrayal, Johnny lifts a TV over his head and throws it out a window. You can easily tell that the TV is fake because Johnny acts like it weighs next to nothing. Any decent actor would at least make it look like it was heavy.I don't understand how so many people can watch this movie and say it was one of the best films they had ever seen. Either they are stupid and retarded or they were paid good money to write fake reviews and give it a good rating.Either way, I just wasted an hour and a half of my life that I'll never get back........I wonder if I could sue the directer for wasting my time?

reviews.review_title: 2 stars for I don't want to see it
reviews.content:
I suspect this is one of a few recent movies, see my review for Rabid (2019), that, IMO, seem to have been deliberately botched, in order to appeal to a niche audience - the "it's so bad, it's good" crowd or to tick off people "I can't believe you liked that junk!" "Phony good reviews!" etc ... No thanks.----------------------------------------------------------------
1 Deliberately botched
2 I don't want to see it
3 I didn't finish and or FF'd through it
4 Bad
5 I don't get it
6 Good
7 Great but with a major flaw
8 Great
9 Noir with moral
10 Inspiring with moral.

Apparently the aliens from Contact who watch our TV broadcasts and try to find ways to respond to us have been eyeing late night cable drams with "sin" or "temptation" in the title and this is what they sent back. Or else the kids from the remedial English class got their hands on a camcorder and decided to make an internet sex tape, and the aliens from Contact were watching that...If anybody has a better explanation for how a movie like this, a movie with no conception of human behavior or interactions on any level could exist, I would love to hear it. Even the worst movie makers manage to hit a correct dramatic note every once in a while by sheer statistical accident. But here, the writing and acting manage to fail with such unerring consistency that it is almost an achievement. Words such as 'surreal' do not begin to describe the experience of watching this movie. Its sheer terribleness on every possible creative level exceeds description. If you took ninety minutes of clips from a South American soap opera, spliced them together in random order and got blind street junkies to come with dubbed dialogue, you would still have a more coherent drama. The Room is so totally bad for every moment of its running time that it becomes a master class on cinematic ineptitude. The dialogue is awful, yet the actors still manage to make it seem much worse than it is by mistiming lines and giving inappropriate responses throughout the movie. The pacing of every scene, every exchange, seems off. And despite a reported budget of $6 million (??!) everything looks cheap and hurried, like a film class project that was left to the last minute.The story construction is so inept that almost nothing that happens pushes the story forward, and virtually none of the plot threads get resolved. In fact, most of them are mentioned once and never come up again. Early on, for example, the mother casually discloses that she has cancer, and that is all we ever hear about it. This however is the film's secret virtue. When no plot point is important or connected to anything else in the movie, the viewer is free to play connect the dots.For instance, Johnny's announcement that he failed to get a promotion at his bank shows his underachievement in the financial world. As financiers are sometimes called 'big swinging d*cks', this could be hinting that Johnny is underachieving anatomically as well. This would explain Lisa' perpetual dissatisfaction with him. Or perhaps Lisa' attitude is actually outwardly redirected self-loathing over all of the Weight Watchers meetings she has been missing. Mark's perpetual surprise over how Lisa's undressing indicates that she wants sex and not something else could be masking his own disappointment that she wasn't handing him her clothes to put on for some cross dressing role play. Such disappointment would go far in explaining the sternness of Mark's resistance to her chubby charms. Danny's drug purchase explains his apparent disconnection from reality throughout the film. The kid is clearly on goofballs. Has the mother's cancer spread to her brain? Memory impairment might explain why she keeps having the same conversations over and over. These are all ripe food for thought, and The Room's arthritic pacing gives the viewer plenty of opportunities to toss them around like footballs thrown by guys in tuxedos.

This is easily the worst movie i have ever seen. Having said that, this is the best movie i have seen in quite some time. i nearly defecated just struggling to concentrate on the story???? as i cried with laughter. Before i go any further i feel that i must mention that this movie cost the director SIX MILLION DOLLARS.......To begin, the sexual intercourse scenes are so perfectly timed with the awful r&b music that her climax and repetition of the fine director's buttocks only increase with the crescendo of the music itself. The camera angle through the waterfall is particularly excellent. I also feel that the amount of lines about how beautiful Lisa is has most to do with the fact that she is not in fact beautiful.One of the better traits this movie has to offer is the uncanny ability for every character to immediately explode in anger and then forgive everyone around them. Apparently every character has taken a bit too many steroids and do not know how to control there hormone levels at all. When we do find any conflict the subject is completely swept under the rug and then they have sex. Its like a mixture between a frat party and the real world and confused Asian tourists all combined to create the personality of this cast, then it was filmed. Also i feel that i have to mention that the old lady had breast cancer. This too was immediately forgotten along with the fact that Denny had some sever drug issues. Which in the words of our dear friend Johnny "hey, that's life".The intense camera angles and beautiful transition scenes were particularly clever because they only added to the confusion of what this movie was about. To add more confusion, they reused cut scenes and added characters without even telling us who they were, this too was very clever and cost efficient.Toward the end of the movie it really got good. Finally the two men fought over the cheating woman. They made up immediately. Then they fought again, Johnny walked away, and with a brilliant cinematic performance by the director/actor/cheap leather coat from Korea salesman, he trashed the set, touched himself violently but sexually with Lisa's dress and shot himself in the mouth.words will never explain this movie, YOU MUST WATCH THIS

It's like watching a TV would be bad, but if someone likes it, great.Surely if he had not had behind him, that one of the worst movie in history, he would not have seen it all.
